tody on the 1st of February, on another charge, in a house in Pear Tree-court, Brick-lane—I saw Redmond find in the room the property which has been produced—I found a pocket-book in the prisoner's coat pocket, con
taining twenty-three duplicates, one dated the 20th of January, for a pair

of sheets, 5s., at Mr. Wood's, in Goswell-street; another, dated January 8th, for a necklace, 3s., at Mr. Hawes's, in Old-street—I went to those shops, and found the articles, which Mrs. Maunder has identified.

Cross-examined. Q. What time was it you went to this house? A. About half-past seven o'clock in the morning—I know it was his lodging, by watching him in there, and by seeing the woman he cohabits with, shake a mat at the door the day previous—I know he cohabits with that woman by seeing them together frequently—I did not find him in bed with her—he was standing behind the door when he opened it—he must have got out of bed to do it—I had been watching him for some considerable time.

HENRY REDMOND . I am a policeman. I went with Brennan, and found the prisoner in his night-clothes—Brennan told him he wanted him, as he considered he had committed a robbery—he took a skeleton key from the mantel-piece, and said, "Halloo, Mr. Russell, what do you call this?"—he said, "it is nothing, you will find more of them—Brennan then went to a table, and asked what was in the drawer—he said, "Nothing yon will find nothing there"—Brennan insisted on breaking it open—he broke it open with a knife, and took out another skeleton key—I found this little box on the mantel-piece, containing this coin, tooth
pick, and hair-guard—in a cupboard I found this dark lantern in a small bag behind a looking-glass;—on the table I found this bunch of skeleton keys, and in a small box by the side of the bed I found a black silk mask, which is used to go over the face—I have also a number of other skeleton key, which Brennan took from a bag, and two crow-bars—part of these keys were in a coal cupboard.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you expected to find all these when you went there? A. Not to many as these—after finding one on the mantel-piece was suspected there were others—I never saw the prisoner in the house except that morning.
JOSEPH JOHN WOOD . I am a pawnbroker, in Goswell-street. I have produced a pair of sheets, pledged by a female, on the 20th of January.

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

944.
CHARLES WILLIAM KEMBLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of February, 1 clock, value 4l.; 1 box, value 3l.; and 140 card-counters, value 5l.; the goods of
Henry Benthall, in his dwelling-house.

JANE WOODMAN . I am servant to Henry Benthall, a ceal and wine-merchant, of No. 18, Cecil-street, Strand. On the 26th of February, be
tween seven and eight o'clock in the morning, I missed the articles stated—I was about my work, and left the street door for about two minutes—the clock was taken from the mantel-piece in the back parlour, and the card-counters from the front parlour—I cannot say how many were gone, but there was a good many.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you leave the street door open? A. Yes, for about two minutes, to go down into the kitchen—the counters were in the box, with a pack of cards—I had seen the clock safe at seven o'clock.

HENRY BENTHALL . My servant came up to my bed-room, and in
formed me of the robbery—I went down, and missed the articles stated—I gave information at Bow-street, and last Friday week I saw and identi
fied some of the article—here is one counter, which has my crest upon

it—my brother brought me a papier macho case, containing counters, from China—each counter was marked with a Chinese device, and engraved with my crest—I should not like to swear to such articles as these, although I have a clear conviction they are my property—the clock has never been found, nor the box—I am certain this counter is one that I lost, by my, crest being upon it.
Cross-examined. Q. That is the only thing you positively know? A. The only thing I wish to swear to positively—these bone counters I do not swear to.

JOHN KIRKMAN . I am a policeman. On the 26th of February, in consequence of information, I went about two o'clock in the morning to No. 15, Peter-street, Saffron-hill, and went to the prisoner's room—he was in bed with two females—I told him I wanted him for a robbery, and to get up and dress himself, which he did—while he was dressing I searched the room—I found these counters on the mantel-shelf, and these four keys on the table—Cole, who was with me, also found some keys, these cards, and some files—the prisoner said, when I found the counters, that a man brought them there the morning before, while he was in bed, to leave them for two hours.
Cross-examined. Q. The counters were not concealed at all, but lying on the mantel-piece? A. Yes—he dressed himself the moment I told him.

JURY. Q. Do you know whether he lived there? A. Yes—the first time I went there I watched two women into the house—I then stopped some time, and when I found they were up stairs in bed, I went into the room—I never saw the prisoner go into that house, but I was informed he associated with the women—I believe he rented the apartment, from what I have been informed.
ROBERT COLE . I am a policeman. I went with Kirkman, and found a quantity of skeleton keys, some hid under the bed, also a quantity of files and screw-drivers—it was the prisoner's lodging.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever see him there before? A. No.
NOT GUILTY .

945.
JOHN JAGER was indicted
for embezzlement.

RICHARD JAMES STAGG . I am a tobacconist in High Holborn. The prisoner was in my employ as traveller—it was his duty to collect money which might be owing to me—he never accounted to me for 2l. 2s. 9d. from George Robert Toplis and another, or for 6s. 11d. from Mr. Pike—it was his duty to account to me when he received the money.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long have you carried on the business in Holborn? A. Nine weeks—before that, I lived in Great Newport-street, Long-acre—the out-door business has been flagging lately—the prisoner did not introduce me to the business—I was originally a bookbinder, but the house my father resided in many years was a tobacco
nists, and being to let, I took it to carry on the business—I knew nothing about the business at that time—I engaged the prisoner, and he got me customers—he got me all the out-door trade—the in-door trade was a good deal, but it was not large enough to carry on business—I fancied the business was increasing at that time, but it has greatly diminished of late—I have got the prisoner to put his name to accommodation paper for

me—I did not take him into custody the day a 19l. bill became due to a Loan Society—I was never a borrower from a Loan Society, nor ever tried to become so—I never commissioned the prisoner to get money, or knew of his doing it—I think I can swear that—he did put his name to a 19l. bill, which became due on the 23rd of February—it was then taken up—I cannot say when I took him into custody—I once gave him 40lbs. of cigars, told him to take a pony and cart, and ride about the country to try and sell them—he did not tell me he had sold 27lbs., and the expenses had been more than the profit—he was to spend what was requisite, there was no limited sum—I never said, when I moved into Holborn, that I thought I was able to manage the business myself now, but did not like to discharge him, for fear he should take away the connexion, nor any thing of the kind—I said nothing to him about wishing to separate from him—I had too much confidence in him at that time—he was not in the habit of hand
ing me slips of paper—I believe he did so once, when I was particularly engaged with some friends in the parlour, and he wrote on the back of one of the tobacco-papers the different sums he had received—I cannot say whether I entered those that night or next day, I do not know which—I know Adolphus Moule—he has occasionally dealt with me—I did not tell him, after I had given the prisoner into custody, that he had received some money which he had not accounted for, but that he had informed me of it, and I had agreed to stop a certain sum out of his wages until I was paid—Mr. Moule did not call on me to ask what the prisoner had done—I have no recollection of seeing him—I never said to him, "I tell you, Mr. Moule, I was rather in an awkward situation with Jager, business has been very bad lately, and he has hardly got sufficient orders to pay his wages, therefore I did not know what to do; if I had discharged him, he would have taken all my connexion away, for many persons would give him orders that would not give me any, and I must prosecute him, or I shall lose the connexion"—I never uttered such a sentence to any body—I said at Bow-street that the prisoner had never put his name to a bill for me to my recollection—he never deducted his wages from the money he re
ceived.
GEORGE ROBERT TOPLIS . I was a customer of Mr. Staggs—I paid the prisoner 2l. 2s. 9d. on the 20th of January for his master—he receipted the bill.

Cross-examined. Q. Who introduced you to deal with Mr. Stagg? A. The prisoner—he used to call and solicit orders from me—I paid him the money on behalf of Mr. Stagg, but I knew nothing of him personally.
PAUL PIKE . I paid the prisoner 6s. 11d. on the 22nd of December, on the prosecutor's account—he gave me this receipt.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you introduced to deal with Mr. Stagg by the prisoner? A. The prisoner was the only person I dealt with.
GEORGE MARSH . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody—he said nothing.

ADOLPHUS MOULE . I am a cap-maker, and live in Horton-street, Clare-market. I have been in the habit of dealing with the prosecutor while the pri
soner was in his service—after he was in custody, I called at the prosecutor's shop—I asked him what the prisoner had done—he said, he had received a sum of money for which he did not account at first, but he told him a little time afterwards that he had received this money, and agreed with

Mr. Stagg that he should take off so much per week from his wages till he was paid; and afterwards Mr. Stagg said, (in confidence like, for I know him very well,) "I tell you, Mr. Moule, I was rather in an awkward situation with Jager"—I said, "How was that?"—he said, trade had been lately very bad, and Jager had not taken orders sufficient to pay his wages with, therefore he did not know what to do; if he kept him he did not want him, and if he sent him away, he would take every one of his customers away, for many customers he had called on would not give him an order, that would give Jager one; and therefore, to save himself, he must certainly transport him—I have no interest in this case, except to tell the truth—I have known the prisoner some years, and did business with him when he kept a shop in Holborn—I always thought him a very honourable young man.
NOT GUILTY .

946.
JOHN JAGER was again indicted
for embezzlement; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
947.
CHARLES CLARK was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of February, 1 umbrella, value 20s., the goods of
Francis Robert Bedwell; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined One Month.

948.
DAVID HATTERSLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of February, 3/4 of a pint of brandy, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Sir Felix Booth, Bart., and another, his masters.
MR. CLARKSON withdrew from the Prosecution.
NOT GUILTY .

949.
JANE TAYLOR and
JAMES JOHNSON were indicted for
a misdemeanor.

WILLIAM HENRY SHEPPARD . I am a haberdasher, Jiving in Whitmore, Hoxton. On the 10th or February, about a quarter-past five o'clock, Taylor came into my shop for a 1d. piece of white tape, which I gave her—she gave me sixpence—I suspected it was bad—I laid it by itself in the desk, and gave her 5d., which she went away with—soon after, I took the sixpence in my hand, marked it, and put it into my pocket by itself—I then went to look after Taylor—I saw her about fifty yards off—I followed her—she joined Johnson, and they seemed in conversation—they then separated, and Taylor went into another haberdasher's, kept by Clark—I saw a policeman on the other side, and told him to take John
son, who was four or five doors off—when Taylor went into Clark's he remained there waiting, looking into a window—I then went into Clark's shop, and told Taylor I wanted her—she said, "What for?"—I told her she must come along with me—I saw Emma Louisa Clark with a sixpence, that she was in the act of bending—she gave it me, I put it into my pocket with the other sixpence, where I had nothing else—I took Taylor into custody myself—she said she was very sorry, would I let her go that time—I took her to the station—I saw Johnson searched, and the piece of tape
I had sold to Taylor found on him—I gave the two sixpences to the constable.

EMMA LOUISA CLARK . My mother is a widow, she keeps a shop at Hoxton. About six o'clock in the evening of the 10th of February, Tay
lor came into the shop, and asked for a halfpenny ball of cotton—I served her—she gave me sixpence—I kept it between my finger and thumb till Sheppard came in—I had not given her any change—I had not let the six
pence go out of my hand—I gave that same sixpence to Mr. Sheppard.
Taylor. You threw it into the till. Witness. No, I did not—I was not in the act of giving you change, I was bending it on the counter.

JOHN JOHNSON (police-constable N 207.) I took Johnson—after he was in custody, he took his left hand out of his coat pocket, put something to his mouth, and swallowed it—after that, as he was going along, he had got his hand clenched, I took him into a potato-shop, and tried to get his hand open, but he got it to his mouth and swallowed something a second time—I received the two sixpences from Sheppard.

WILLIAM SAUNDERS (police-constable N 170.) I assisted to take John
son to the station—I searched him, and found three pieces of tape and a skein of silk, two counterfeit coins, and a 1d. worth of pudding a 4d. piece, and 10 1/2 d. in halfpence—two good sixpences were found on Taylor.
Taylor. The money was passed through two or three hands. Witness. No, it was not.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint. These are both counterfeit, and both cast in one mould.
Taylor's Defence. I did not do it.

Johnson's Defence. I had been to the Rosemary Branch public-house, and met a man—we proposed to go to the play—I came down the road, and saw a white parcel—I picked it up, and put it into my pocket—I went on,' and met Taylor—I asked where she was going—she pulled her
self out of my hand, but I know nothing of her.

TAYLOR—
GUILTY .

JOHNSON—
GUILTY .
Confined Six Months.

950.
ANN HARDING and
SARAH FORBES were indicted for
a misdemeanor.

JOSEPH GLASS . I am landlord of the Dolphin public-house, Well
alley, Wapping. On the 26th of January, in the evening, the prisoners came there, and Harding called for half a quartern of gin and peppermint, it was served them—Harding threw down a bad half-crown—I came out of the parlour, and said, "That is a bad one, it won't do for me"—she gave me a good one—I said I must give her into custody—I called in a policeman—she then said she took it of a sailor, and it was a very hard case—I asked if she knew the sailor, she said she did not—I marked the half-crown, and gave it to the policeman—I declined to give them in charge—they both partook of the gin.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you quite sure that Harding was the person? A. Yes—I had not seen her before—she remained in the place about five minutes—there was only myself, the two prisoners, and the man who served them, there.
JAMES HUNT . I am servant to Glass—I remember the prisoners
coming in—Harding asked for half a quartern of gin-and-pepperinint—she put down the half-crown—I am sure she is the person.

WILLIAM JONES (police-constable T 41.) I was called into Glaiss's shop—Glass produced this bad half-crown to me—he marked it in my presence with a knife—I found the prisoners in the shop—I asked Hard
ing where she got it from, she said she took it of a sailor, that she was an unfortunate girl—I asked if she could point out the sailor, she said not.

WILLIAM THOMAS BUYER . I keep the Gun and Arrow public-house, at Wapping. On the 2nd of February the two prisoners came together—Forbes asked for half a quartern of gin and spruce—my wife served them—Forbes put down a bad half-crown, my wife took it up in my presence, and said it was bad—Forbes said that they had taken it for work done—I would not take it—they paid me—one had 1 1/2 d. and the other a halfpenny—I let them go—Forbes took the half-crown—I looked at it enough to satisfy myself it was bad—I followed them out, they went round by Wapping-church—they stopped there, under the lamp, three or four minutes—in two or three minutes I saw them cross over to Mr. Shaves's, the Turk's Head—I went in, and made a communication.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure Harding was one of then? A. Yes—it was a quarter past seven o'clock in the evening—I did not take the half-crown into my hand—I could see it as it laid on the counter.
CHARLES SHAVE . I keep the Turk's Head public-house, Wapping. Since this I have had the misfortune to lose my wife—she was examined at the Thames police-court.
COURT. Q. Did you attend with her? A. No.
GEORGE LEADLEY . I am clerk to the Magistrate of the Thames police-office. I took the examination of Mary Shave—she signed it—she was examined before the prisoners on oath.
Cross-examined. Q. You do not know that she was the wife of Mr. Shave? A. No.

GEORGE WM. GRAVE (police-sergeant K 11.) 1 saw Mrs. Shave at the Thames police-office—I had known her as the wife of Mr. Shave for years—(read)—"Mary Shave says, I am the wife of Charles Shave—on Tuesday night last, a little before eight o'clock, the two prisoners came in together —Harding called for half a quartern of gin and spruce—I served them with it—Harding put what I thought was a half-crown down—I put it into the till, where there were two new half-crowns—I gave her 2s. 4d. change—they went away—in a few minutes Mr. Bryer came and spoke to me—I went and looked at the half-crown, and it was bad—I marked it and gave it to Grave, the officer—I am sure it is the same—no one came in till I went to the till when Bryer came in."

GEORGE WILLIAM GRAVE (police-sergeant K 11.) I was called on the 2nd of February to assist Mr. Bryer—I went with him after the prisoners—I saw them go into Mr. Shave's, the Turk's Head public-house, about 150 yards from the Gun public-house, together—! waited outside till they came out—they then separated, and went on different sides of the street—they walked perhaps a quarter of a mile—I kept them in sight—at last Harding crossed, and joined Forbes—I went and asked them if they had been into a public-house—they both said, "No"—Harding then said, "Not lately"—I took them to Mrs. Shave, who identified them as the persons who called for the gin and spruce—Harding said, "I was not aware it was a bad one," and she offered a good half-crown—this is the half-crown I received
from Mrs. Shave—on Forbes I found six shillings and 7d. in copper, and on Harding a good half-crown and some other good money—they said I they lived in. Ratcliff-cross, which I found was not true.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin to the Mint. These half-crowns are both counterfeit.

HARDING*—
GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Two Years.

FORBES—
GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

951.
THOMAS DONOVAN and
MARTIN WELSH were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of February, 250 needles, value 1s. 4d. the goods of
Mary Ann Besant and another.

ELIZABETH HUXTABLE . I am shopwoman to Mary Ann Besant and another, in Oddey's-row, Islington. On the 27th of February, between twelve and one o'clock, Donovan came and asked to look at some buttons—I showed him the drawer—he looked and said they were not cheap enough for him, and asked to look at some needles, which he did—he said they would not do, they were too expensive for him—he then went out—I did not miss any needles till the policeman came, which was in about five minutes—we then saw that some were gone—these ten papers of needles I believe are my mistress's—I am sure they had been safe when Donovan was in the shop, and no one else came in.

GEORGE HAZARD (police-constable N 126.) I was on duty near the prosecutrix's shop about a quarter to one o'clock, and saw Welsh alone—Donovan came and joined him—I did not see where Donovan came from—they went on to another shop—I took Welsh) and found these ten papers of needlesson him.
CHRISTOPHER NORTH (police-sergeant If 17.) I was on duty and saw the two prisoners together a quarter before twelve o'clock.
Donovans Defence. I had been out of work, and a young man I met gave me these things to sell.

DONOVAN—
GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

WELSH—
NOT GUILTY .

952.
THOMAS DONOVAN was again indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of February, 116 shirt-buttons, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Henry Green.

WILLIAM HENRY GREEN . I live in Penton-street, and am a linen-draper. On the 27th of February Donovan came to my shop about twelve o'clock at noon—he asked to look at some buttons—he did so, and went out without buying any—on the Monday following the policeman brought these buttons, which are mine—I had not missed any.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How many are there? A. Nine dozen and tan—I have sold as many as twelve dozen, but not at one time, and not in one week—all that I sell have the same mark on it.
NOT GUILTY .
(There was another indictment against Donovan.)

953.
WILLIAM KEMP was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Feb
ruary, libs, weight of tobacco, value 2l., the goods of the
London Dock Company.

JOHN CLEMENT . I am a constable of the London Docks. On the 27th of February the prisoner was acting as a weigher in the Customs at the dock—I saw him coming out of the gate of the dock that afternoon into

Ratcliff-highway—I said "Kemp, have you any tobacco about you?"—he said, "No, not a bit"—I said he must go back with me, and while going back—he said, "I am a ruined man, I am a done man"—I took him into the lobby, and found inside his drawers 9lbs. of leaf tobacco—I asked where he got it—he said he found it in the tobacco-warehouse, and was going to take it home—I told him he must go with me to the station, but we had scarcely got two yards when he turned and ran away—I pursued—he turned and made a blow at me—I warded it off, and closed on him—I took him to the station—he there asked to go to the water-closet—Dix went with him, and he produced 2lb. more of tobacco.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Had this tobacco paid duty! A. No, if it was for town trade, it would pay duty before it left the docks—the duty is upwards of 3s. a pound—the prisoner was in the service of the Customs—I cannot say what his pay was—he told me it was a guinea a week—I went to the lobby gate on purpose to stop him—he had passed a revenue gatekeeper before he came to me.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did the prisoner say he had smuggled it? A. No—it is the property of the Dock Company until it is sold, and is then delivered to the purchaser.

GEORGE HUMBERSTONE . I am foreman cooper in the tobacco ware-house at the London Docks—the prisoner was at work there—there was some tobacco there of this quality—there has been some taken from there.
GEORGE DIX . I heard the prisoner say he was going to take the tobacco home to help to maintain his wife and children.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 36.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Year.

954.
SAMUEL JOHNSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of February, 5 handkerchiefs, value 1l. 1s.; and 12 yards of lace, value 6d.; the goods of
Robert Udall.

EDWIN ALLEN . I am apprentice to Mr. Robert Udall, of Edmonton. On the 2nd of February, the prisoner came to his shop between one and two o'clock, and asked for some things, but did not buy any—he went away—I recollect showing him a drawer which had some silk handkerchiefs in it, and there was a box of lace on the counter—the next day he was brought past the shop handcuffed—I inquired what he had been doing—I then looked and missed five handkerchiefs and some lace—this now pro
duced is one of the handkerchiefs—I am sure it is my master's, and it had not been sold—I had sold one of them the day previous—this lace we can swear we had the same day, and the same pattern—the quantity I do not know.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What is this handkerchief worth? A. 5s.—I know it as it had been creased with another, which was sold the day previous—here is the one that was sold, and the creases, which are accidental, exactly correspond—I never said there was a cut in it—I said there probably might be a cut—I did not point out any cut—I looked to see if there was one, and there was not—I have been in a pub
lic-house near this Court, with the policeman—I asked him, when we were there on Saturday, to let me see the handkerchief, and to compare them, in case of any request from the Judge—I then inquired for a knife.
Q. Did you say that as there appeared to be a place in the corner of one of the handkerchiefs cut, you would cut the other to correspond? A.

No, I wanted the knife in case I should be flurried in speaking before the jury—I never cut the four corners of the two handkerchiefs that I might easily put them together—nor that they might be more like each other, but that I might put one corner to match the other—1 swear I did not cut a hole in one of them—I was in company with the policeman—he did not leave' the room at all—there was a gentleman there making out a brief, and I think there were two or three other persons there.
COURT. Q. On your oath, had you any other object in wishing to compare them again, than to fortify your identification of them? A. No.
SARAH GUDGEON . I bought one of these handkerchiefs of Allen, the day before, and it has these creases in it that he speaks of.

ROBERT BUTCHER (police-sergeant N 37.) When the prisoner was in custody, I asked him his address, and he gave me Spicer-place, Peckham New Town, but I found it was at No. 1, York-street, Walworth—I found this lace and this handkerchief there.

Cross-examined. Q. You went to a house kept by Mrs. Hicks? A. Yes—it is a four-roomed house—the prisoner afterwards told me he lived at No. 1, York-street, Walworth—I let Allen have these handkerchiefs, but they were not out of my sight.

HANNAH HICKS . I live at No. 1, York-street, Walworth—I let a room there to the prisoner and a woman—the prisoner has not been there con
stantly—he has been there sometimes for a week and away for a fortnight— the woman is his wife, as far as I know—I have only one other lodger there.
Cross-examined. Q. When had yon seen the prisoner there? A. Two days before the policeman came.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

955.
JOHN CLARKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of February, 27lbs. weight of veal, value 16s., the goods of
Charles Reeves: and that he had been before convicted of felony.

CHARLES REEVES . I live in Gray's-inn-lane, and keep an eating-house. On the 21th of February I missed 27 1/2 lbs. of veal, which had hung outside the window, 10 1/2 feet high—I saw it again, and am able to swear it was mine—the person must have got up the side of the wall, as there were the foot-marks.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What was it? A. A hind quarter—I saw it at six o'clock that evening—I then went out, and did not see it again till eleven at night.

HENRY WEBB (police-constable G 106.) I was on duty on Saffron-hill, about a quarter past six o'clock—the prisoner came down with the veal on his shoulder—he got into White Horse-alley, and I took him—I showed the veal to Mr. Reeves, he said it was his property.
JAMES PARRY (police-sergeant R 8.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Transported for Seven Years.

956.
NICHOLAS JOHNSON was indicted
for embezzlement.

ROBERT WILLIAM PEARCE . My wife is a milliner and lives in Regent-street—the prisoner was her errand
boy—it was his business to take out goods, to receive money, and to account to nay wife or to Miss Hensball—I discharged him on the 14th of February—after he was gone, I found

him in Charles-street, Middlesex Hospital—I said, "I suppose you know me?"—he said, "Yes"—I said, "I am come respecting Mrs. Redman's money"—his countenance changed, and he said, "I have not received it"—I said, "You have—I have sent to that lady, her servant paid you, and has your receipt, which she can produce"—he denied it, and I gave him into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You discharged him, but not for any fault? A. He had many faults, but I was not aware of this—my wife is not here—the prisoner did not say, that if he bad received this, he had accounted for it.

ELIZA HENSHALL . I am forewoman to Mrs. Pearce, of Regent-street On the 5th of February, I sent the prisoner with a cap to Mrs. Redman—it was his duty to receive the money and to account to me on his return—I particularly told him there was a bill in it, and a receipt to it, and that he was to wait—he went with it—the next day was Saturday—I was not well, and was not there—I saw him on the Monday morning, and asked him for the money—he said she had not paid him, as she had a party there, or was going to a party and did not pay him—I asked him if he had taken the receipt off the bill, he said he had, and had got it somewhere—he attempted to look for it, but did not produce it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you put the receipt in the box? A. No; the young person who makes out the bills told me it was there.

ELIZA EMMA MANNING . I am housemaid to Mrs. Redman, of Canton-place, Limehouse. On the 5th of February the prisoner came, and brought a cap in a box—I took it to my mistress, and when it was opened I saw the bill in it—no part of it was torn off—my mistress gave me 2l. 3s., which I paid to the prisoner—this is the bill and receipt.
Cross-examined. Q. What time was this? A. A little after seven o'clock on Friday evening.

ANDREW WYNESS (police-constable D 43.) I went to the lodging with Mr. Pearce, and saw the prisoner—he said he had not had the money—I put my hand on his arm—he squared up to me, and said he would knock my head about.

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined four months.

957.
GEORGE DURHAM was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of February, 2 loaves of bread, value 1s. 7d., the goods of
James Whiting.

ANDREW GLASS . I am servant to Mr. James Whiting, a baker, who lives at Pimlico. I was out with bread on the 27th of February—I left my barrow, and missed two loaves—the policeman brought them to me—I knew them, they were my own making.
Prisoner. Q. Were they of one baking? A. Yes, stuck together—I was not gone away above two minutes and a half.
JOHN PEARSON (police-constable B 69.) I saw the barrow in the street—the prisoner was about a hundred yards from it, and had these two loaves—I took him, and the witness owned them.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought them in Pimlico.

GUILTY . Aged 41.—
Confined One Month.

958.
HANNAH WRIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of March, 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
George Ferguson.

PHOEBE BROWN . I am shopwoman to Mr. George Ferguson, of Wbitechape), On the 1st of March, about four o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came in for a pair of shoes at about 2s. 6d.—I showed her a pair of single soled ones—she said she wanted a pair of double soled ones—I then went to speak to a shopman, and as I turned I saw a pair of shoes under the prisoner's arm—(she had not bought any)—she was then going out—Mr. Ferguson came and told her she had stolen a pair of shoes, and she took them from under her arm—she had removed them from the counter to the door—these are my master's property—the prisoner said she had plenty of money, but she would not show it to me.
SILVANUS GILL (police-constable H 55.) I took the prisoner—I asked her if she had any money to pay for the shoes—she said she had plenty—I searched her, and she had not a farthing.
Prisoner's Defence. I told you 1 had no money; I wanted a pair of shoes for 1s. 9d.; she went and spoke to the man, and then said I had stolen a pair, which I had not.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Three Months.

959.
GEORGE CHARLES CUNNEIU was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of March, 80 yards of silk lining, value 4s., the goods of
John Cheek.

ANNE SHENTON . My husband is shopman to Mr. John Cheek, of the Strand. I was on the stairs about eight o'clock in the morning, on the 3rd of March, and saw the prisoner come into the shop, put his hand on the glass case, and take out this silk linings—he put them into his left-hand pocket—there was no one in the shop—I told my husband when he came up—he collared the prisoner, and sold him he would give him in charge—the prisoner took the linings out of his pocket himself, and put them down.

Prisoner. I asked a boy the price of them; he said his master would be up directly and tell me; when the man came I asked him the price, and he collared me, and said if he" could he would send me to Newgate. Witness. You had not seen my husband; they were in your pocket when he came; you had ordered 7l. worth of canes a few days before; you asked the boy if they were done, and while the boy was gone you took these.
EDWARD SHENTON . I am the husband of the last witness. My wife told me of this—I collared the prisoner, and told him to take these out of his pocket, and he did so.
Prisoner. Did I not ask you the price, and offer to pay for them? Witness. No.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Four Months.

960.
WILLIAM IVES was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of Feb
ruary, 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l. 10s. and 1 1/2 yard of kerseymere, value 9s.; the goods of
Richard Dunn, his master.

RICHARD DUNN . I am a tailor, and live in Golden-square. The pri
soner was my errand-boy up to the 15th of February—I missed a pair of trowsers and a piece of kerseymere—these now produced are them—I have compared this kerseymere with the piece it was cut from.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Have you other servants? A. No, only one maid-servant.
THOMAS WILSON . I am in the employ of Mr. Harrison, a pawnbroker.
I produce these trowsers—I took them in of the prisoner on the 10th of February.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you got the duplicate? A. Yes—it is in the name of William Jones—I see hundreds of persons in a week—I saw the prisoner again, ten days after, at Marlborongh-street—he was pointed out to me as the person taken on Mr. Dunn's charge.
CHARLES WHITE . I am a pawnbroker. I have the kerseymere, but the person who took it in has left us.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

961.
MARTHA SAUNDERS was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of February, 1 half-crown, 8 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
James Fry, from his person.

JAMES FRY . On the evening of the 25th of February I was in Oxford-street—I had 11s. in my pocket; amongst it was one half-crown, and either one sixpence or three—the prisoner came and took hold of my arm—I put her away two or three times—she followed me to Tottenham-court, when I thought I felt her hand in my pocket—I put back my arm, and caught her arm between my arm and my side—I found my money was gone, and said, if she would give me back my money I would not give her in charge—she denied having it—a scuffle ensued, and a girl came up—I again asked the prisoner for my money, and she gave me 2s., and said she had no more—the officer came and took her.

JOHN GEORGE RESTIEAUX (police-constable E 49.) I came up and found the prosecutor had hold of the prisoner—I asked her what money she bad got—she said 2s.—I took them from her, and at the station I found a half-crown in her other hand, and I received 2s. more from the prosecutor.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

962.
WILLIAM DELL and
JOHN COLLARD were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of February, 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Griffith Humphreys; and that Collard had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN KNIGHT . I am shopman to Griffith Humphreys, of Oxford-street. On the 26th of February, about seven o'clock in the evening, Dell came to the shop for a pair of socks—I showed him some—he wanted me to look for some more—Collard then came in, and stood by the side of him—they did not appear to know each other—they did not speak—Collard did not ask for any thing—while I was turning to get the other socks, Collard took the handkerchief off the counter—I caught hold of both of them, and kept them in the shop till the policeman came—I saw this handkerchief drop from under Collard's coat.
THOMAS TKINGJIAM (police-constable E 18.) I have frequently seen the prisoners together—I know that they know each other—I think I saw them together the day before this.

WILLIAM CUMMINOS (police-sergeant D 13.) I took the prisoners and received this handkerchief—Dell said, "I know nothing of the other per
son; I was in the shop before he came in."
Collards Defence. I went in for a stock to put inside my handkerchief.
Delll's Defence. I was at home all day on the 25th; I was taken on the 26th.
WILLIAM CUMMINGS (police-sergeant D 13.) I produce a certificate of Collard's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—he is the person who was convicted.

DELL—
NOT GUILTY .

COLLARD—
GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Transported for Seven Years.

963.
JAMES MOORE and
EDWARD THOMPSON were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of March, 8 pieces of wood, value 9d., the goods of
Thomas Cubitt.

DUNCAN GRANT . I am private watchman to Thomas Cubitt, at Thames Bank. About twelve o'clock, on the 2nd of March, I saw the two prisoners going towards a pile of deals—Moore took up this piece of deal, and walked away with it 200 yards—he then broke it into small pieces, and Thompson assisted him and tied it up in a bundle—I went and took Moore—he re
sisted—I went and called a policeman—when I returned they were making away with the wood among the vacant places in the stones.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Do you know whether Moore's father is employed on the premises? A. No—Thompson was walking close to Moore when he took the wood—I do not know whether Moore had been taking his father's dinner—it was after Moore began to break this up that Thompson assisted him—one of the masons employed on the place was helping them to put the wood away—I do not know his name—Thompson split up part himself—he did not attempt to get away—he said nothing at the time.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

MOORE—
GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

THOMPSON—
NOT GUILTY .

964.
HENRY CORTNEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of March, 1 gave, value 2s. 6d.; and 1 brush, value 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Geeves.

SARAH CLARKE . I am servant to Thomas Geeves, who keeps the Queen's Head public-house—on the 2nd of March I was up stairs, and saw the prisoner in the bed-room—I asked him what he was doing—he went away—I gave information to my master—I missed the gown now produced, which is my master's.

THOMAS GBEVBS . I keep this public-house. On the 2nd of March I received information from Clarke—I began to see if all was right—the pri
soner had no right in my bed-room—I found my gown was gone—I sent two people in search of the prisoner—I found him in a court in Maiden-lane—he had thrown down the gown and brush in the court—I did not see him do it—it was my wife's gown—not five minutes had elapsed between my finding the gown and the prisoner's going down from the room—it was safe at twelve o'clock, and this was nearly five—no one else had been in the room.

WILLIAM MELEY . I live in Off-alley. I was in the public-house, and saw the prisoner coming down stairs with something under his coat—I could not see what it was—I ran and overtook him, and he threw the gown down.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in a state of intoxication.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Six Months.

965.
GEORGE HAWKINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of March, 1 box, value 3d.; and 48 cigars, value 2s.; the goods of
Edward Mitchell.

ALFRED MITCHELL . I live with my father, Edward Mitchell, a tobac
conist, in Albion-place, Islington. On the 3rd of March I was behind the counter—the prisoner came in, and asked for two halfpence for a penny—I turned my back, and missed a box of cigars—I went out, and saw him walking round the corner with it under his arm—I ran after him—he saw me, and ran away—he was stopped, and brought back with it—this is the box and cigars.

Prisoner. The witness said that two labouring men brought the box, and I was taken half an hour after; he denied that I was the person when I was first taken. Witness. No, I did not—I have no doubt that he is the person who took them—I was always sure he was the person—I said it was him directly.
ROBERT BRAY (police-constable N 178.) I searched the prisoner, and found the two halfpence on him—I produce the box of cigars.

GUILTY .** Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

966.
BERNARD HENRY BODEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of June, 1 watch, value 3l., the goods of
James Dingley.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Sarah Damond.

JAMES DINGLEY . I live in Rochelle-place, Lamb's Conduit-street. I have known the prisoner from twelve to fifteen months—on the 8th of June I sent a gold watch to Sarah Damond, in Bull-and-Mouth-street, by the prisoner—he was to deliver it there, and receive the money for it—I had sold it to her—he ought to have received five guineas, or an undertaking that he had delivered it—I never saw him again till the 26th of February.

Prisoner. In what capacity was I employed by you? Witness. I em
ployed you occasionally.
SARAH DAMOND . I live in Bull-and-Mouth-street, St. Martin's-le-Grand. The prisoner brought the watch on the 8th of June, as I heard, but was not at home, and he did not leave it—this is the watch.

WILLIAM UNDERWOOD . I am assistant to Mr. Attenborough, in Shore
ditch. I have the watch—it was pledged on the 10th of June, to a young man who has since left, in the name of Henry Benson.
CHARLES BURROWS (City police-constable, No. 335.) I took the prisoner—he said he knew nothing about it.

Prisoner's Defence. I never do jobs for the prosecutor—I know no
thing about it.

JAMES DINGLEY
re-examined. I received a letter and the duplicate from his brother—I went to his brother about it—I know his brother's hand-writing—I swear this letter is his writing.

GUILTY. Aged 25.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined Three Months.

967.
PAUL JOHNSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of Feb
ruary, 3 tons weight of coal, value 3l., the goods of
John Ray.
The goods not being the property of John Ray, the prisoner was

968.
JOHN GRIFFITHS and
MARK GOODYER were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Richard Whiting, at St. Sepulchre, on the 28th of February, with intent to steal, and stealingtherein, 1 box, value 6s.; 74 sovereigns, 48 half-sovereigns, 4 shillings, and 2 sixpences; 13 handkerchiefs, value 20s.; 2 waistcoats, value 10s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 2s. 6d.; 3 printed books, value 2s. 6d.; and 1 knife, value 2s.; the property of the said Richard Whiting.

RICHARD WHITING . I am ostler at the Old George Inn, Snow-hill, in the parish of St. Sepulchre. I live in the room over the warehouse—it is my dwelling-house. On Sunday, the 28th of February, I had a box con
taining the property and money stated in the indictment—I left it safe about three o'clock—I came to the place next about seven in the evening, and found the staple of the warehouse-door was broken, the staple of my room door was drawn, and the box and its contents gone—I have got it and the money back.

JEASON CLEMENTS . I am under ostler there. I went to Sharp's-alley, Cow-cross—on being alarmed, I saw Griffiths standing with the box on his shoulder, and Goodyer standing by his side—I took the box—both the prisoners ran away—I did not say any thing to them.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you say nothing to any body? A. No—I took the box home to my fellow-servant.

WILLIAM HALSEY . I live in Jerusalem-passage. I was in the tap-room, went up into the prosecutor's room, and missed these things—I went up Holborn-hill, and saw the two prisoners running up the hill as fast as they could run—I saw a policeman, and told him I believed they were the parties who took the box—I had seen them down at the place before—Griffiths was taken—Goodyer ran back, and I took him in Hatton-garden—he said, "For God's sake don't lead me into it, I am a ruined man about the d—d box"—I gave him in charge.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen the parties about the place that evening? A. Yes—I had seen Goodyer there on the Saturday before—I do not know what Griffiths is.

CHARLES BULL (City police-constable, No. 288.) I took the prisoner Goodyer—he wanted to know what for—I said I would tell him directly, and when he saw Halsey, he said, "I see how it is—it is a done job."

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ask him how he came to be with Grif
fiths? A. No—he said some confused sentences about kings, and what I could make nothing of.
(Edmund Smith, of Webber-row, Waterloo-road, gave Goodyer a good character.)

GRIFFITHS—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

GOODYER—
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Ten Years.

969.
SAMUEL WHITE and
MARIA BOWDEN were indicted for
a misdemeanor.

DANIEL SUGG (police-sergeant H 17.) On the evening of Thursday, the 28th of January, I went to No. 120, Rosemary-lane, to the first floor back room—I found White there, sitting by the fire-side, and this child was lying on some rags, upon two choirs—I told White I had received in
formation that he had been ill-using the child—he said he had not used it ill—I asked him where it was—he said, "Here it is"—asked him to show it me—he took it up by one arm, and showed it me—the child screamed out, and appeared very much hurt—the officer who was with me remon
strated with him—the child had two black eyes, a cut across the nose, and

the head appeared very much bruised—its body and chest was very much emaciated—I left him, and went off for the parish-surgeon—the prisoner said nothing about how the child got the black eyes—I asked him if he was the father—he said, "Yes" at first, and then he said he was not—he said his wife was out at work at Green-bank—I went, and found Bowden—I said I wanted her for neglecting the child, and starving it—she said she was a poor woman, and did what she could for the child—it had been ill some time—she said White was not the father of it, and it was three years old—she said she had been to the parish for relief for it, or for them to take it—I find she is a poor woman, obliged to go out to work—White took the child to the workhouse.
White. Q. Was the child on a rug, or on the ground? A. It looked like a ragged sack.

JAMES DAVIDSON (police-sergeant H 12.) I went to the house—my brother officer knocked at the room door, which White opened—we found the chair close to the door, where he had been sitting, in front of a small fire—I told him we came by information, in consequence of his ill
using a child—I asked where the child was—he took it up by one arm—it was either sitting or lying down—it was dark—I asked if he had a candle—he said, "No"—I went up stairs for a candle, and saw the child sitting down close by two chairs, on some rags—he took the child up, it had two black eyes, and seemed cut or scratched about the face—the head seemed to be in a very poor state—it had not the least appearance of swell
ing—I asked him what he fed it with—he said, "Gruel"—I asked what he had in the saucepan—he said gruel for his own feeding, and it was all he had—I told him to put some out, and give it to the child—the child seemed quite ravenous, and flew at the basin—I said, "Don't let it have it till it is cold"—he then said he had a tea-pot that he gave it drink from—he brought it to the table, and the child tried to seize it—I asked how the child got bruised in the face—he said it was by falls—this piece of cord was there—I asked him what he did with this—he said it was what he chastised the child with—I spoke to him about using such means to such a child—he said he could not keep it quiet, it was continually crying—I took him into custody—I asked him to take the child down to the workhouse—he said he had no objection.

MARY ANN SEALE . I lire in Rosemary-lane—I am unmarried. The prisoners lived together, as man and wife, in the back-room, first floor—I live in the front-room—the man went by the name of Mr. White, and the woman Mrs. White—they came there about four months before they were taken—they brought a child with them—I saw the child about three weeks after they came—it then had a sore on its bead—I do not think it was ill at that time—it used to want drink constantly—on the Monday before the prisoners were taken, Bowden came into my room—I heard screaming in their room before she came in, and I heard something fall—I then heard Bowden say, "Get up, Carey, and come away from him"—a month before that, White washed the child's ears with salt and water, and there was a cut in its ear, and several lashes about the body—White was washing it at that time, and Bowden was holding the candle—I saw marks, as if it had been beaten with a cord or cane, in front of her bosom, and across her back and loins—Bowden seemed as fond of the child as I should expect—I have seen White beat the child, and knock her down with a sack—I have interfered with him, and he threatened to kick me down stairs, and called

me very ill names indeed—when Bowden has locked the child up, she has come home ahout twelve o'clock—I do not know what she gave the child—it used to sleep on a sack—there was a bed in the room, hut White never would let the child sleep on the bed—about three weeks before they were taken I heard the child cry, and heard Bowden say, "You monster," after the child had cried out—there was no one else in the room—I had gone into the room, and seen them there.

White. Q. Did you come into the room whsn you saw me knock the child with the sack? A. Yes—I used to have the key of the room to see to the child, and when I spoke of the ill usage of the child, you would never let me have it any more.

ELIZABETH FORD . I know the prisoners and the child—I saw it in Seal's room about two months before the prisoners were taken—I took up the child's petticoats, and it was marked about the body with a cord or cane.

White's Defence. I maintained the mother and child for the last twelve months; the last four months I fell out of work; we have been very badly off, and we were forced to live on gruel; the child fell out of bed; the mother went to the workhouse, but they would not give her a loaf of bread; Seal said she would do for me, and try to put me into prison if she could.

WHITE—
GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined One Year in the Penitentiary.

BOWDEN—
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Second Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
970.
ROBERT JAMES JACKSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of February, 1 coat, value 5s.; and 3 frocks, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
George Christopher Hymns.

ELIZABETH HYMNS . I am the wife of George Christopher Hymns, and live in Long-alley, Moorfields—I go out nursing and charing. The pri
soner's sister lodged with me, and paid me 1s. a week—the prisoner used to come to see her—on the 9th of February I went out, at seven o'clock in the morning, leaving the prisoner's sister in the room—as I was coming home, about eleven o'clock, I met the prisoner in Ball-alley—directly he saw me he threw down something in a bundle—the sleeve of my child's frock fell out, and I knew it—the prisoner ran away—I could not stop him—I gave him in charge afterwards—he said when taken that he did not wrap up the bundle—that was another bundle, which I found in the room, wrapped up in a flannel—he asked me to forgive him several times.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. I believe you found him in bed at his mother's? A. Yes—he seemed very much cut up about it, and cried.

WILLIAM KENCHETT (police-constable G 26.) I accompanied the pro
secutrix to the prisoner's mother's—he begged for forgiveness several times—while I stood out on the landing, I heard the prisoner's sister in the room, chastising him, because he did not take the key to the prosecutrix, as she had directed him.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you ask him, as you took him to the station, who tied up the bundle which you found in the room? A. I did.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 14.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Month.

971.
SARAH BECKWITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of March, 1 crown, the monies of
William Kimbrell, from his person.

WILLIAM KIMBRELL . I am a servant out of place. I met the prisoner on the evening of the 3rd of March, and asked if she could show me the way to a private lodging-house—she said she could, and was going to show me—as she went along she asked me to give her a glass of gin—I said I had no money—she said, "Yes, you can stand a glass"—I said I had a few halfpence, and gave her a glass—I afterwards went down to Burford's, the pawnbroker, and pawned my watch for 8s., having no money—I got a crown-piece, a half-crown, and a sixpence—I was counting it in my hand—she asked me to stand some ale—I said, "This is every farthing I have got to pay my lodging and all"—she caught the crown-piece out of my hand, patted me on the back, and said, "Never mind, you shall come and sleep with me to-night"—I called out, "Give it me"—she would not, but walked away—I followed her to a house, and she went up stairs—I went up after her—it was a dark place—I said, "Give me my money"—she struck a light, and said, "Come, you shall sleep with me, stand a drop of ale"—I gave her a quart of ale, and she would not give it me then—then a woman came up to the room, and said, "Oh, here is my husband coming, if he sees you in the room there will be a terrible row"—the pri
soner went down, and I after her—she went to the Running Horse public-house—I said, "Give me my money"—she would not answer me—I gave her another quart of ale there—there wa four of them there—they went to another public-house, and had some gin—I followed them, to see if they spent my crown-piece there, but they did not—they brought me a glass of gin to the door—I again asked her for my crown-piece—she walked back to the Running Horse—she saw a man coming, and said, "Oh, my G—, here is my old man!"—Me came and drove her home, and said he would knock my eye out—I followed them to the house, heard them bolt the door, and then I ran off for a policeman.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you know her before? A. No—I did not know her name till she was before the Magistrate—a police
man went by while I was at the public-house door, but I did not give her in charge then—I did not go to any bed-room except at the first place—I stood by the door perhaps twenty minutes—she said, "Come and sit down"—then the woman came and said her husband was coming.

WILLIAM LYONS . I am a policeman. I was on duty in Old Brentford, and took the prisoner for stealing the crown—she said she had never had it at ail, and about half an hour afterwards she said he gave it to her.
Cross-examined. Q. Had not you seen them talking together? A. Yes, at the door of the Running Horse public-house—she did not appear the worse for liquor, nor did he.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Transported for Ten Years.

972.
JAMES NUTT was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of February, I looking-glass and stand, value 15s., the goods of
Alexander Hubbard.

ALEXANDER HUBBARD . I live at Little Chelsea. On the 19th of February, about half-past five o'clock in the evening, this glass was inside my shop—I missed it, and saw it again at the pawnbroker's—I know nothing of the prisoner.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. It there any mark on it? A. Yes—I have not a doubt of it, I have mended it myself.

CHARLES TEHU . I am servant to Mr. Ravenhouse, of Queen's-build
ings, Brompton. This glass was pawned for 6s. on the 19th of February, between six o'clock and half-past by the prisoner, in the name of Adam.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite certain of him? A. Quite—I never saw him before—he was nearly twenty minutes in the shop.

— KAY. I am a policeman. I took him in charge at the pawn
broker's—he at first denied having pawned it, but before he left the shop he said he bought it of a man in Brompton for 8s., and pawned it half an hour afterwards, as he was distressed.

Cross-examined. Q. Has there been any other person indicted about this glass? A. No—a policeman of the V division came to Queen-square to identify a person there, and he said he saw a person coming with a glass similar to this in the direction from the prosecutor's on the evening it was lost.

JANE NUTT . I am the prisoner's sister. I was with him on Friday evening, the 19th of February, when he bought the glass of a man near the Red Lion public-house at Brompton—the man had on a long dark coat, that is all I recollect of him—my married sister, Harriet Sherwood, was with me at the time—I do not know what became of it after he bought it—we left him, and went to my sister's house at Kennington-street, Knightsbridge—he went away with the glass.

COURT. Q. Tell us the exact time this happened? A. It was about six o'clock in the evening—it happened opposite the Crown and Sceptre public-house, not a quarter of a mile from Mr. Ravenhouse's, the pawn-broker—my brother works for Mr. Bigley, a market-gardener—he was in place there at the time—he does not deal in glass—this did not take long—the man who had the glass spoke first—he asked 10s. for it—my brother would not buy it for a considerable time, at last he gave him 8s., and then the man went away—the man was coming from towards Knights-bridge—my brother did not past by the name of Adam, I never heard him called by that name—he pawned the glass for 6s.—I heard that from him—he did not inquire how the man got it, or why he was selling glass in a public street—he had the appearance of a hawker—I cannot tell why my brother should pawn it in the name of Adam—I did not know he had pawned it in that name.
JURY. Q. Did you meet your brother in the street? A. I came from home with him.
— KAY re-examined. He said at the station there was no person with him when he bought the glass.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Where was it you asked him if he bad any body with him? A. The inspector at the station told him he might say any thing he thought proper, but what he said would be given in evidence against him—he then asked whether he objected to say whether any body was with him when he bought it—he said no, there was not, and he told me in the station afterwards that nobody was with him—he said he had bought it in the street at Brompton for 8s.
(The prisoner's other sister being called, did not appear.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Twelve Months.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
973.
MARY DOYLE was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Febru
ary, 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. 4d.; and 11 shillings, the property of
Joseph Johnson, from his person.

JOSEPH JOHNSON . I live in Orange-street, Bethnal-green. On the morning of the 27th of February I went to the Black Swan public-house, in Schoolhouse-lane, Limehousc, I got drunk, and fell asleep—I had 15s. in my left hand trowsers' pocket—when I awoke a little after four o'clock I had only 2s.—I had spent 2s., and had lost 11s.—I had seen the prisoner all day in the house—she was gone when I awoke—I also lost a pair of stockings from my coat pocket.

WILLIAM BURN . I was at this public-house all day. I was going past the tap-room door, and saw the prisoner's hands in the prosecutor's coat pocket, and taking out a pair of stockings—I took them from her, and put them into his pocket again—I did not see her hand any where else.
PHILIP HENRY . I was in the tap-room. I saw the prisoner put her hand into the prosecutor's coat pocket, and then into his trowsers—after I heard some money link, and she put her hand in her bosom.

GUILTY.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

974.
MICHAEL WALSH was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

GUILTY . Aged 35.—
Confined One Year.

975.
MARY ANN MIDDLETON was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of January, 2 blankets, value 5s. 6d.; 2 pillows, value 4s. 6d.; 1 sheet, value 1s. 6d.; and I looking-glass and frame, value 6d.; the goods of
John Smith: and that she had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN SMITH . I keep part of a house in Vine-street, Saffron-hill. On the 27th of January the prisoner hired the first floor of me—after I heard something I went and missed the articles produced, from the room—they are mine.
HENRY HALL . I am a pawnbroker in Baldwin's-gardens. These two blankets and the other articles I took in pledge from the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I did it through distress.

JOHN KENT . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)— the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Confined One Year.

976.
JAMES FRANCIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of February, 1 bridle, value 14s.; 1 pair of reins, value 2s.; 1 collar, value 10s.; 1 saddle, value 13s.; 1 pair of traces, value 5s.; 1 martingale, value 3s.; 1 pair of hames, value 6s.; and 1 crupper and breeching, value 7s.; the goods of
Thomas Kibble.

WILLIAM PITT . I am horse-keeper to Thomas Kibble, a cab
master in Portland-street. I left my stable about one o'clock on the 19th of Febru
ary—I was coming back, and met the prisoner with this set of harness on his back—it had been removed out of the stable—I thought a neighbour in Wardour-street had borrowed them, and I watched the prisoner to see whether he took them there, but he passed by—I then inquired at the shop, and pursued the prisoner—I overtook him in Rath bone-place—I

put my hand on his shoulder, and asked him who lent him that—he said, "Mr. Somebody"—I took him back to the stable—I found a policeman, who took the prisoner—the stable-door was not locked, but the hasp I was on.
Prisoner's Defence. I was under the gateway—a man who looked like a coachman came and told me to take it to Mr. Jones, in the New, and he would give me 2s.—I was going, and the witness stopped me.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Six Months.

977.
SAMUEL WOTTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of February, 5 bushels of oats, value 12s., the goods of
Charles Thomas Hol
combe, his master.

JAMES BLACK . I am steward to Mr. Charles Thomas Holcombe, he lives at Barking, the prisoner was his carter. On the 12th of February he was to go for a load of manure with an empty cart—I had frequently missed oats from the granary—on the night of the 11th of February, I smoothed the oats over, and in the morning I found the print of two holes in the oats, and about five bushels gone—Salmon, the other carter, came to me with two handfuls of oats—I compared them with those in the gra
nary, and they exactly corresponded—I believe them to have been part of the same—I afterwards saw the marks of some, feet without shoes, as if they had had worsted stockings on, walking up to a wall, and there was an im
pression, as if a sack had been dropped, with something heavy in it, over a nine-feet wall—the prisoner had no right to go into that granary—it had been locked, and the person who entered must have got in at a window, after getting over the wall.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Was there no fastening to the window? A. Yes, a common iron latch, which a person outside could open, as there was a broken pane in the window, for cats to go in and catch mice—the window was shut in the morning, as I had left it—I kept the key of the granary—I believe it is a patent key—I have known the pri
soner about two years—I never Keard of any dishonesty in him—he is married, and has five children—I missed about two bushels of white oats, and three bushels of black oats, which I suspect were taken that night— the white oats were Scotch oats, and rather a particular sort—they had been cut rather green—the black oats were common—Salmon brought me a handful of oats out of each sack, a little after six o'clock that morning—I got up about six—I live on the premises—when Salmon came to me, I found the prisoner had been gone about a quarter of an hour—Salmon has lived on the same premises five or six years—Mr. Holcombe has been thereabout three years, and Salmon has been in his employ constantly—he has never been discharged—there was a man named Warren in Mr. Hol
combe's employ—I heard that the prisoner had caught Salmon in the stable, opening his bin with a false key; but it was not Warren told me of it—I called Salmon and the prisoner face to face in the stable—I do not recol
lect whether it was stated, on that occasion, that Salmon had gone into the
stable after all the other men had left—it might have been stated, without my hearing it.

Q. What was the object of your calling Salmon to face the prisoner? A. To tell him he had done wrong in opening the bin—each man has a bin for the food for his horses for the week—I did not tell Salmon that he had gone into the stable at night, and opened the prisoner's bin with a false key—the prisoner had charged Salmon with going to his bin in the night; but he did not repeat it before Salmon's face—I heard of it from a great many quarters—the prisoner never told it to me to my recollection—I will not swear he did not—it was stated, on that occasion, that Salmon opened the bin with a key; and I suppose it was a false key.

Q. Did I not ask you whether the prisoner complained that Salmon had opened his bin with a false key? A. I believe it was so—Salmon did not deny that he had done so—I told him I had a good mind to send him about his business—I might tell him to go—I believe I did tell him to go.

Q. You say you saw the mark of a sack having been thrown down; was it not hard frosty weather? A. No, it was not a frost that night; it was a thaw—the white oats would weigh about 40lbs. a bushel, and the black about 38lbs.

FRANCIS SALMON . I am a carter in the employ of Mr. Holcombe. On the morning of the 12th of February I saw two sacks in the cart—one of them was three parts full, and the other about half full—it was Mr. Hol
combe's cart, and the prisoner was the driver—I examined the sacks, and found there were oats in them—I took some black oats out of one sack, and some white ones out of the other, and took them to Mr. Black—I saw the prisoner drive the cart away—I do not know whether the sacks were in it then—I did not look into the cart any more.

Cross-examined. Q. What time did you go to the stable that morning? A. About ten minutes past five o'clock—the prisoner was then inside, just opening the great gates into the yard—he went away with the cart about a quarter past six, which was about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes after I had seen the sacks in it—I was in the stable with him all the morn
ing—I did not say any thing to him about the sacks, as I did not know but that Mr. Black might have ordered them—the cart was about a dozen yards from the stable door—when I took the oats out of the sacks, the prisoner had gone with his horses to the pond to water—I took them to Mr. Black after the prisoner left—I could not take them before, as Mr. Black was not moving—I could have awoke him—his house stands in the garden; but I thought he would soon be out, and I did not like to disturb him—I did not examine the sacks in which the oats were—I never had any quarrel with the prisoner—we might have had a few words in contradic
tion—I swear I have not had words with him in anger half a dozen times.

Q. Do you remember going to his stable one night, when all the men were gone? A. Yes—I went to do my work, I suppose—I unlocked the prisoner's corn-bin with a key which Mr. Black gave me, because I had a suspicion that there was corn there which ought to have been in my bin—I found more in his bin than there ought to be—I did not take it out—the prisoner came to me there—his hat did not fall into the bin close by me—that I swear—he did not ask what I was doing, nor did I tell him—I sup
pose he could see what I was doing—I did not beg of him to say nothing about it—I swear that—I cannot recollect all I said to him—I did not beg
of him to have mercy on me, and say nothing about it—he did not threaten to tell my master nor Mr. Black of me—nor any body—I never heard him say any thing of the kind.

Q. Did he not say that he had found out why his horses did not look so well as the other men's? A. He said his horses would look as well as others if they had the same victuals—Mr. Black spoke to me about it, and he told me to go about my business—I went home, but I did not leave the service—I went again—Black had not given me any money to go off—he was in a passion.

WILLIAM RICHARDSON . I am a police inspector. I was on duty at Ilford station about half past seven o'clock in the morning on the 12th of February, and received information from Mr. Black—I went up the road, and saw a cart driven by the prisoner—I passed it at Stratford, and got a small distance in front of it—I desired the sergeant to keep in the rear of it—I proceeded to the Bell-and-Mackerel public-house—I saw the cart driven to the door—a man came to the prisoner, and he stopped about a quarter of an hour—the prisoner then drove on, accompanied by the other man, who had fed the horses, into Ducket's field, which is out of the main road—I then saw the man who had fed the horses get into the cart—I saw him take two empty sacks out, and place them on the hind ladder—the sacks were the wrong side outwards, and had oats hanging to them—I then desired the officer to take the prisoner, and to take care of the sacks—the sacks were the prosecutor's—the oats have never been found—the prisoner had got three miles and a half from his master's before I overtook him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he draw up at the Three Pigeons? A. No, he did not stop there—from what I had heard I had reason to believe the property would be left at the Bell and Mackerel—I kept in front of him about two miles—when I first saw the sacks they were empty, and they were making preparations to fill the cart with dung—the sacks were merely moved to prepare to load the dung.
NOT GUILTY .

978.
JOHN MACGIBBERING was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of February, 15 buns, value 7 1/2 d., the goods of
Frederick Beacham; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined Five Days, and
Whipped.

979.
ROBERT WITHAM was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Lucy Fox, about twelve o'clock in the night of the 20th of February, with intent to steal, and stealing therein 9lbs. weight of cheese, value 6s. 9d.; 6lbs. weight of bacon, value 8s. 6d.; 5 loaves of bread, value 2s.; 1 1/2 lb. weight of butter, value 1s. 6d. 2oz. weight of to
bacco, value 6d.; 1 yard of baize, value 6d.; 1 knife, value 1s.; 1 sixpence, 3 pence, 9 halfpence, and 8 farthings; the property of the said
Lucy Fox.

LUCY FOX . I am a widow, and live at Woodford-bridge, in the parish of Woodford, with my two nieces. I keep a chandler's shop—on Satur
day night, the 20th of February, about twelve o'clock, I retired to bed—I had shut up my little shop—it does not lock, but shuts with a latch inside, and cannot be opened outside—the shop adjoins my house—I got up about seven o'clock the next morning—I was informed a pane of glass had been cut out, and the inner screw taken out, which would enable a person to open the window and get in—I missed the cheese and bacon, and the other things stated—it appeared as if somebody had been in the place and ran
sacked it—the drawers were open, the till was taken out and set on the
counter, and the money stated taken from it—I have seen the property since—it had the appearance of being mine.

MARY JOHNSON . I live with my aunt, Mrs. Fox—I retired to bed about twelve o'clock—I was the first that came down the next morning—the shop was then broken open, and the property gone—I had not heard any one in the night.

SUSANNAH FISH . I recollect the prisoner coming to me on the Sunday morning, between nine and half-past nine o'clock; he tendered me some farthings—I thought they were bad, he said they were good—he gave me eight farthings, and asked me to give him 2d. for them, which I did—I marked one of the farthings—this is it.

MARY JOHNSON
re-examined. I missed some farthings from the till, I cannot say how many—I know two of these farthings produced by Mrs. Fish—I offered them in the shop on the Friday, and Saturday they were refused as being bad.

GEORGE FORTUNE (police-sergeant K 42.) I traced the footsteps to the back of Mrs. Fox's premises—I had suspicion of the prisoner, and compared his shoes with the footsteps—they corresponded exactly, nail to nail.

JAMES WHITE (police-sergeant K 13.) I compared the prisoner's shoes with the marks with George Fortune—the property was found concealed in a dunghill; it was in a putrid state, and could not be produced—the pro
secutrix saw it.

GUILTY of Stealing only. Aged 31.—
Transported for Seven Years.

980.
PATRICK MURPHY was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of January, 1 ring, value 3s.; I star, value 3l.; 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, 1 crown, 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence, the property of
Charlotte McLean: and
JOHN MILES, alias Sweeney
, for feloniously receiving 1 star, part of the said goods, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.—2nd COUNT, for receiving 3/4 oz. weight of silver.

CHARLOTTE MCLEAN . I am widow of General Sir Joseph McLean; I at present live in Wood-street, Woolwich. On the 24th of December I resided at Woolwich Common—my house was destroyed by fire that night, and the furniture that was saved was moved to a stable in the Royal Artillery barracks at Woolwich—about a fortnight after the fire I saw a star of the Hanoverian order of Knighthood at the Commandant's house—it was in a chest of my drawers—I had possession of the keys of the drawers—some of the furniture was afterwards removed from the stable to Wood-street—the military assisted in moving it—after it had been so removed I examined the drawer in which the star had previously been, and it was missing—there were marks of the lock being broken open, picked, as if the drawer had been forced—I also missed a gold ring which was cracked, and a purse with some gold and silver in it—I afterwards saw some pieces of silver at the Commandant's house at Woolwich, which decidedly belonged to the Hanoverian Order, but there was not the whole of it—it was mutilated.
JOHN BALLANTINE . I am a bombardier of the Royal Artillery. On

the 20th of January, I saw Murphy and a soldier named Hardy, they were on fatigue, moving her ladyship's baggage—they brought two chests of drawers from the Artillery barracks to Wood-street—I noticed the top drawer of the chest, it was firm and secure—I afterwards locked up the stable of the house in Wood-street—I had previously left Murphy and Hardy in the stable where the chest was—I missed them for a few minutes and asked what kept them there so long—they said it was so heavy, they could not get the things properly placed—on the following Monday, the 25th, I went to the stable with her ladyship, and found the drawer open.

DAVID DAVIS . I am a pawnbroker, and live at Woolwich. About the 22nd of January, Miles came to my shop in the evening, and asked if I bought old silver—I said, "Yes"—he said he had some in his pocket, which he would show me—he produced what appeared to have been a star of some order, broken in pieces—I asked where he got it from—he said, "From Spain"—I said he must get some one to prove it was his property—he said he could easily do that—he left the shop, and returned with the prisoner Murphy—I asked Murphy what he knew about this cross—he said he knew it belonged to Miles, and that he (Miles) had brought it from Spain with him—I asked Murphy his name—he said, "Murphy"—I asked him what he knew it by, how he knew it belonged to Miles, and what sort of a star it was—he said it had marks all over it, and the lion and unicorn on it—the star had no lion and unicorn on it—Miles called him-self Sweeney—they were dressed as they are now (as soldiers)—I told them I should apply at the Commandant's house, and told them to meet me there next morning—I sent the silver to the Commandant's house that evening, with the particulars of the affair—this is the silver now produced.

CAPTAIN JOHN SOMERVILLE . I am a captain in the Royal Artillery. On Monday, the 25th of January, in consequence of information, I had all the men who had been employed in moving Lady M'Lean's furniture, collected, and brought to my quarters, having a sergeant-major with me—I examined them all separately, having Mr. Davis by me at the time, to get him to recognise any of the men—when it came to Murphy to be ex
amined, I saw at once from the way he answered, that he was a suspicious person, and on questioning him about the star, he said be had not a star, but he knew a man that had—he then gave me the name of Miles—I sent for him, kept them separate, questioned them, and in a very short time I got them to contradict each other—Miles told me that the star which he had brought from Spain, he broke up in Spain before he brought it home, and Murphy told me that he saw it in Miles's possession, a short time before, whole—Miles said he had got it from some fort in Spain—I then went with Miles to the guard-room, and held out some expectation, if he told me the truth, that it would be better for him—he then told me that what he had told me before was all false—I afterwards sent for Hardy—the silver produced was given to me at the Commandant's office, by the person who brought it from the pawnbroker's—I was present when Miles made a statement before the Magistrate—it was precisely the same as he had communicated to me—I had told him I would stand between him and punishment, if he would tell me the truth—Miles has been only four months in the regiment, and Murphy eleven or twelve, and both bore a very good character.

ROBERT HARDY . I was engaged with Murphy in moving some articles to the stable in Wood-street—Murphy got a nail, and knocked the lock off the chest of drawers in the stable—I went out to bring in some more

things, and when I returned he showed me a star, a purse, a sovereign and a half in gold, some silver, and a cracked ring—I told him to let them alone, and have nothing to do with them—he laughed at me—I saw the bombardier at the door, but did not hear him speak to us.

LADY MCLEAN
re-examined. These pieces of silver are decidedly por
tions of the star, but the centre part is missing.
Miles's Defence. I throw myself on the mercy of the Court, being a young soldier, and not knowing it was stolen.

MURPHY—
GUILTY . Aged 21 .—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Months.

MILES—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

981.
MARY HUDSON was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Poole, on the 4th of February, and stealing therein 1 coat, value 2l. 10s.; and 1 pair of gloves, value 1s.; his goods; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

982.
JOSEPH DEAN was indicted
for unlawfully, maliciously, and feloniously assaulting
