Edward Wiseman, on the 5th of February, and cutting and wounding him in and upon his left eye and left eyelid, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

EDWARD WISEMAN . I am apprentice to William Fisher, of Greenwich, and live in Coomb's-court. On Friday, the 5th of February, I went to the house of a woman named Hambrook, in Rose-street, Greenwich, about half-past eleven o'clock at night, to look after two of my fellow-appren
tices —I was intoxicated—I found them there—there were two girls in the house—I went up stairs with one of them—while I was down stairs I re
ceived a blow on the head, by which I lost the sight of my eye—I lost my senses after that blow.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was there any girl with you there? A. There was one there—I went up stairs with her—I did not have a clothes prop at all during the whole time—my fellow-apprentices were both sober—nothing was done to the prisoner at all that I saw.

JOHN CARTER . I am apprentice to Mr. Fisher. On the night of Fri
day, the 5th of February, I was at Mrs. Hambrook's with my fellow-ap
prentice, Josiah Smith—the prosecutor came there about eleven o'clock—he was intoxicated—after he had been there some time he went up stairs with a girl in the house—it is a brothel—he came down in about three mi
nutes in a hurry—the prisoner was below—the prosecutor said in his hear
ing that the girl had taken his money—Mrs. Hambrook wanted to put him out—the prosecutor and the girl went up stairs again—I am sure of that—the girl came down stairs—he gave her the money, and they went up again—she took the 1s. which he gave her—they were up about a quarter of an hour the second time—when he came down he said she had robbed him, and had his money, and Mrs. Hambrook wanted to put him out—the pri
soner was still below—he did not say what she had robbed him of—the girl said nothing about it, but Mrs. Hambrook took hold of the prosecu
tor, and tried to shove him out—she did not try to push him out the first time he came down, but she tried to push him out the second time—the prisoner got up, apparently to interfere, as he thought the prosecutor was going to hit Mrs. Hambrook—he got up to hit the prosecutor, to take Mrs.

Humbiook's part—the prosecutor had not struck her—Smith jumped up directly, to take Wiseman's part, and he held the prisoner's hands for about a minute—the prisoner wrested away from Smith, and flew to the fire
shovel, and before Smith could get out of the door, he hit him over his hand with the shovel—Wiseman fell against the wall, being intoxi
cated, as he was trying to get out—he fell as he was getting out, and as he was falling, the prisoner hit him over the eye with the fire-shovel—he did not repeat the blow, nor try to repeat it—he did not lift his hand to strike again—I saw nothing to prevent him doing so—he made a second blow, and was going to strike him again—I did not understand the ques
tion before—I went up to him, and he said, "Have you got any thing to say against it?" and was going to make a blow at me—I escaped out of the door—he had still got the shovel in his hand—I returned, and found Wise
man lying at the bottom of the stairs, bleeding—I went and got him out—there was nobody with me—the prisoner said he lived in the house—he said he kept the house.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. He said he kept the house? A. Yes; he said he lived at Mrs. Hambrook's, and she kept the house—he said he was commander—he said he lived in the house, and looked after Mrs. Hambrook—I cannot say that he used the word "commander"—if the pri
soner bad wished to strike Wiseman again, when I went out of the house, he was at his mercy—I had been in the house about four hours and a half—Smith went with me—we bad been drinking—Mrs. Hambrook fetched what we had, at our desire—we had come from home—I and Smith both had the clothes-pole—it was broken in two, and I and Smith both took a part—this was after we had escaped out of the house—it was standing in the yard—I first laid hold of it when I escaped out of the door the second time—I and Smith did not make use of any expressions when we came back, no fur
ther than saying, if he was to come out we would serve him out—I do not remember saying, "Come out, you b—"—I will not swear I did not say so—I swear positively I did not use such an expression, nor Smith either—we might have said, "We will have your life, or you will have ours"—I believe we did say it—the prisoner had not been up stairs in bed—he came in after we had been there four hours—Wiseman did not attempt to make a blow at Mrs. Hambrook, and the prisoner interfere to prevent it—Wise
man did not do, or try to do, any thing.

COURT. Q. Did Wiseman use any violence towards the prisoner? A. No; no one had done any thing to the prisoner, more than hold his hands, before he got the shovel—it was after the blow was given that we said, "We will have your life, or you will have ours."

JOSIAH SMITH . I was at Mrs. Hambrook's house—I remember Wise
man coming there—he was intoxicated—he went up stairs with a girl, and came down again soon after—he said the girl had got his money—he went up again—the girl came down, and he came running after her, and said she had got his money—Mrs. Hambrook wanted to put him out—I was sitting in a chair, and saw the prisoner scrummaging with Wiseman—they were holding one another, and, by the appearance of it, the prisoner was going to strike him—I got up out of the chair, and held Dean's hands for about a minute—he no sooner got from me than he flew to the fire
shovel, and I made my escape out of the door as soon as I could—I received one blow on the head, and one on the hand, I cannot tell what with—I waited outside a few minutes for the prosecutor, and in a few minutes they

opened the door—Wiseman was bleeding on the stairs, and there was, I should think, upwards of a pint of blood on the stairs—after that he came out and went home—I waited there till I saw an officer, and gave the prisoner in charge—I went in again—I had nothing in my hand—we had a clothes-pole before, but we did not take it into the house with us—we had it out
side the door—we had it in case he should come out and strike us again—it was in one of the yards—each of us had part of it—we broke it and di
vided it—Carter had come outside—we only stood there waiting for Wise
man to come outside—I do not know what particular words we said—we said something—I cannot recollect that I threatened the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Perhaps you will tell me you only had the poles to defend yourselves if attacked? A. Yes—we did not ask him to come out, we did not threaten to take his life—I would not do such a thing—neither of us called him a b—I am quite sure Carter did not desire him to come out, and say he would take his life, nothing of the kind—I did not hear it—the prosecutor walked out by himself—I think the officer helped him up off the stairs—I went in with Carter to take him out—I was not altogether sober—I do not know whether Carter was—Wiseman was not, Carter was—I cannot answer for his being exactly sober, he appeared to me to be sober—I should think we were out of the house about twenty minutes—we left Wiseman inside all that time—we were standing by the door the greatest part of the time, but we did not offer to break it open, as it was locked—when the officers came they made him open the door, and we went in—the officer was with us when we went in and got Wiseman out—I had not the stick in my hand when the officer came—we put them down when we saw the officer come, not having any fear—we never made use of the sticks.

JONATHAN SHEPHERD (police-constable R 105.) I went to Mrs. Ham
brook's on the 5th of February, near upon one o'clock—I was called by Carter and Smith—I could not get in for a short time, somebody inside said they had lost the key, and could not open the door—it was afterwards opened—I went in, and saw there had been a good deal of blood on the lower part of the stairs—it had been wiped down, but was very visible—Wise
man was gone home then—Carter and Smith had no sticks in their hands that I saw—Wiseman must have been gone, according to what they stated to me some little time—Smith was bleeding from his hand when I went in—I asked him what it was—he said a man who had been inside was cut with the shovel in the eye, and bleeding—I asked where he was—they said they had sent him home—I saw nothing of Wiseman that night—I had heard the wit
nesses talking outside, I thought there was too much noise, and returned to see the cause of it—they met me at the end of the passage, told me this, and I got admittance—the prisoner said he was willing to go—he did not say he lived in the house—he gave his address, and said he lived in Bridge-street, Greenwich—(looking at his deposition)—this is my handwriting—it was read over to me after I signed it—I do not recollect that the prisoner said he lived there, Mrs. Hambrook said he did.—(The witness's deposition being read, stated—"I took the prisoner into custody at Mrs. Hambrook's—he said he lived there, and the others had no business there, that the others had struck him, &c.")—It ought to have been written, "She said he lived there."
Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure Wiseman was gone before you mule? A. Yes, there is no mistake about that—it was their loud talking that brought me to the place.
COURT. Q. Is the shovel you have what you found on the premises? A. Yes—I could discover no stains of blood on it—I found it in Mrs. Hambrook's room, close by the stairs, packed away under a table.

JOSIAH SMITH
re-examined. Q. You have heard what the policeman says—you told us you got in by means of the policeman? A. I did not rightly understand what you said—Wiseman had gone home before that—I got in twice—it was the second time when the policeman came—they had locked the door after we got Wiseman out, and we waited till the officer came—before we got Wiseman out I did not hear Carter say, "I will have your life, or you will have ours."
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you not been talking to Carter since you left the box? A. No, I only said one word—I was asking him whether be thought we should be able to go away to-day?

FREDERICK COTTON FINCH . I am a surgeon. I saw the prosecutor on the morning of the 6th of February—he had a compound wound—there was contusion and laceration of the globe of the eye, and loss of sight altogether—the sight was gone when I saw it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he attend to your instructions to take care of it? A. On one occasion, four days after, I found him over a fire instead of lying in bed.

ANN SULLIVAN . I am an unfortunate woman. On the night in ques
tion I was at Mrs. Hambrook's house with Wiseman—I came down with him, he wanted to pick up a quarrel with the prisoner, and made use of very bad expressions, and said he would knock his eye out—the prisoner, being in liquor, got up, and said, "You had better knock my eye out"—I went out, and when I returned I saw the prisoner and pro
secutor hustling together—they forced the door open, went out, and tried to break the fence down to strike the prisoner—they took a prop, broke it, and Smith came out with one piece in each hand, and said, "Dean, come out, you shall have my life, or I will have yours"—Wiseman had been struck, but I was not there then.

COURT. Q. Why did you not stay to see what happened? A. I had occasion to go outside the door—I was there when the policeman came, sitting by the fire-side—I was not there when they took Wiseman away—I was coming up the court when they were bringing him down—that was about twelve o'clock—the policeman came about half past twelve—they came and knocked at the door, as if they wanted to come in again, and I nearly had a blow on my head with the prop—they had been drinking there nearly all the evening.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

983.
THOMAS DAY was indicted
for embezzlement, to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

984.
THOMAS DUNN was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of Feb
ruary, 1 loaf of bread, value 4 1/2 d., the goods of
John William Palmer; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 56,—
Confined One Month.

985.
THOMAS ROBERT RITCHINGS was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of February, 1 watch, value 14s.; 1 watch-guard, value 6d.; and 2 watch-keys, value 9d.; the goods of
Henry Frederick Harvey;
and 1 watch, value 10s.; 1 watch-guard, value 6d.; 1 watch-key, value 2s.; and 1 seal, value 1s.; the goods of
Lucy Charlotte Harvey', his mistress; to all which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

986.
JAMES MITCHELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of January, 1 coat, value 1l., the goods of
Michael Burns; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

MICHAEL BURNS . I live in Erith parish. On the 13th of January I was in the Coach-and-Horses' public-house, at Woolwich, and I saw the prisoner there—I then went to the Crown-and-Mason public-house—I pulled off my coat, and laid it on the table—I began dancing—I told Elizabeth Han
cock to look after my coat—after dancing, my coat was gone, and the pri
soner also—I have not found it—the prisoner was in the room while I was dancing.

ELIZABETH HANCOCK . I was at the public-house—the prosecutor put his coat on the table, and told me to watch it—I took it up, and gave it to the prisoner—I asked him if he would hold it till the prosecutor had done—when I saw it last the prisoner had it under his arm, and was sitting near the door—when the dancing was over, the prisoner and the coat were gone.
WILLIAM RICHARDSON . I am a tailor, and live at Woolwich. I was at the public-house, and saw the prisoner deliberately walk out of the room with the coat either on or under his arm.

Prisoner. I saw the man that owned the coat two months or ten weeks ago, and he challenged me with the thing I am now arraigned for—he said, "I saw you in a public-house two months ago"—I said, "Why did you not get somebody to take me?"—he said he was not well—I have been about Woolwich ever since. Witness. This occurred in January, 1840, and he absconded for six or seven months.

DANIEL RIORDAN (police-constable R 207.) We had information of this, and were looking after the prisoner for six months. I produce a cer
tificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the man—I had him in charge.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Transported for Seven Years.

987.
SUSANNAH SEAGER was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of February, 1 pair of stays, value 5s. 6d., the goods of
John Sharland and another.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Robert Baldery.

ROBERT BALDERY . I am a dealer in stays, and live in London-street, Greenwich. I assigned my property over to John Sharland and another, as trustees—on the 8th of February the prisoner came for work as a straw
bonnet maker—I was in the parlour when she came in—I saw her take a pair of stays, and conceal them on her person—I let her remain till my wife came up—I then called my wife and my servant into the shop, and charged the prisoner with having the stays—she denied it—I sent the ser
vant for a policeman—the prisoner then said, "Don't be hard with me; I will pay you for them"—she produced them from under her cloak.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. These goods are not your's?.

A. They were assigned to my creditors on the 4th of February—John Sharland and another are the trustees—they receive the money for the produce of the stock—the prisoner had worked for my wife occasionally between three and four years—I never knew any thing against her—I be
lieve she said, after the policeman was in the room, that she was going to bargain for them.
WILLIAM O'BRIEN (police-constable R 192.) I took the prisoner—she was crying, and wished Mr. Baldery not to give her in charge.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 44.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Month.

988.
JOHN FREDERICK was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

GEORGE ADAMS . I am a baker, and live in Hill-street, Woolwich. In the evening of the 8th of February, the prisoner came to my shop, and asked for a penny loaf—I cut him a pennyworth of bread, and he tendered me a shilling—I took it up, and said, "This is a bad one"—he said, "Is it?"—I said, "Yes, it is; and I think you know it"—he said, "You had better link me"—which means, to handcuff him—I said, "Is that what you mean? I think you are what I term a smasher"—I had the shilling in my hand, and said, "I will mark this; and if you can prove you got it legally, you shall have it; if not, I will not give it you"—I marked it, and put it into my left-hand pocket—he wanted to have it—he got to the shop-door, and abused me in very bad language—I kept it apart from all other money till the 16th of February, when I gave it to Riordan.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What mark did you put on it? A. A cross on the head—he said he got the shilling from a woman at Greenwich.
DANIEL RIORDAN (police-constable R 207.) I produce the shilling I received from Mr. Adams.

ELIZA COCKLE . I am the wife of Benjamin Cockle, who keeps a beer-shop in East-street, Greenwich. On the 11th of February, the prisoner came between six and seven o'clock in the evening—he asked for a half-penny pipe of tobacco—I served him—he gave me a sixpence—I gave him 5 1/2 d. change, and he went away—I bit the sixpence, and it was bad—I put it under a tumbler on the shelf, and gave it to the policeman on the following Monday, when he came for it—he told me to mark it, and I notched a piece out of the side.

JOHN WALKER (police-constable R 182.) I took the prisoner about ten o'clock in the evening, on the 15th of February, at Greenwich—I found on him 8d. in copper, a 4d. piece, a biscuit, and a halfpenny loaf, and on a man who was with him I found 10s. in silver, 6d. worth of copper, five pipes full of tobacco, and five halfpenny-worths of thread—I have the sixpence which I got from Mrs. Cockle.

SAMUEL EDWARD FREEMAN (police-sergeant R 3.) I saw the prisoner searched by Walker—he threw a small bag on the table, which he took from the prisoner, and it was supposed to be empty—I found in it this sixpence.
JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These two sixpences and this shilling are all counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

989.
JAMES LOWRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of January, 3 1/2 lbs. weight of mutton, value 2s. 4d., the goods of
John Sil
well; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

990.
JAMES MURDOCK was indicted
for embezzlement; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Six Months.

991.
GEORGE POWELL and
DANIEL MUNDAY were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Ann Rochester, on the 28th of February, and stealing therein, 1 watch, value 2l.; 2 watch-keys, value 2s.; 1 watch-chain, value 6d.; and 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l., the goods of
Thomas Rochester: and 1 coat, value 1l. 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 4s.; 1 table-cloth, value 5s.; 1 sheet, value 1s.; 1 shirt-front, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; 5 stockings, value 1s.; 1 half-crown, and 3 shillings; the property of the said
Ann Rochester.

ANN ROCHESTER . I am a widow, and live in Salamanca-street, Vanx-hall-walk, in the parish of Lambeth. I rent the house—on Sunday even
ing, the 28th of February, I went to church, about half-past six o'clock, leaving the house quite safe—the windows were all fastened, I am confi
dent, and the doors all shut and fast—I left them all on the lock and bolted—the back-door was bolted, and the street-door on the spring lock—I was fetched from church about eight o'clock, and found every thing turned out; I found my son at home—I had left him in the house when I went out—the articles stated in the indictment were gone—my son's watch was hanging up when I went out—the coat and waistcoat belonged to ray hus
band—the table-cloth and stockings, to me—I found a drawer turned out, there were two coats and other clothes brought down stairs and laid in the passage—I found the parlour "window open—I had left it fastened, and put the shutters to, but did not fasten, them—I can swear to all the articles found, the waistcoat, stockings, and table-cloth.

THOMAS ROCHESTER . I live with my mother—she went out that evening at half-past six o'clock, leaving me in the house—I left the house quite safe at twenty minutes to seven—I locked the door, and put the keys in my pocket—I did not touch the parlour window—I returned at ten minutes to eight, and saw a light up stairs—I went and tried to open the door, but it was bolted inside—I heard somebody run down stairs—I ran down the back way, called out "Thieves," and saw two boys come out at the back door—I never lost sight of Munday, who was one of them—a man named Timpson took him in my presence—I am confident of him—Powell was the other person, I am certain—I saw him run towards the back door of the next house—they both jumped over the fence— Powell went to the next door, and was found in the shed—he was brought back in a few minutes—I am certain he was the man who came out of the door.
Powell. Q. What do you swear to me by? A. You jumped over
the paling when you were taken—there was a gas-lamp at the bottom of the garden.
Munday. Q. Did not you say there were three people jumped over the paling? A. I was not confident whether there were three or two.

ROBERT TIMPSON . I am a carter, and live next door but one to Mrs. Rochester—I heard a cry of "Stop thief," ran out, and caught Munday—I brought him back—Rochester directly he saw him, took him—I went to search the house—I did not see the other.

SARAH PARSONS . I live next door to the prosecutrix, in Salamanca-street—I heard a cry of "Stop thief," about eight o'clock that evening—I ran to the front door, and heard them say, "They are in Parson's gar
den"—I ran through the passage to the garden—Munday was brought up to my back door, and the policeman came and took him—after the mob had dispersed, I went into the garden to look for my candlestick, and as I was going to the shed with a light, I saw Powell screwed up in a corner—he knocked my light out—I screamed, he put his fingers into my month, and I bit them—he drew his hand out—I held him tight by the collar, until a policeman came—this shirt-front laid by his side in the shed.

Powell. I was not in the shed until she shoved me in there—I called out, "My dear woman, 1 am no thief"—she came accompanied by a young man—she seized me, and tried to strangle me, and said, "I will stick you if you don't stop;" and the man also seized me round the waist. Witness. It is false.
WILLIAM HARWOOD . I was with Mrs. Parsons. I did not shove Powell into the shed—Mrs. Parsons had got him in her hand, when I came up—she was trying to hold him.
JOSEPH HOLLIS . I went to search this "house after the prisoners were taken, and found this watch in a sink just out at the back door adjoining the garden.

JOHN MACK . I am a policeman. I received charge of Munday—I found on him two handkerchiefs, a large knife, a piece of bent wire, and a halfpenny—the wire and knife would, I dare say, enable a man to open the prosecutrix's window—I tried it myself—I could put it between the sashes, but could not pull back the catch—I did not understand the nature of it.
Munday. The handkerchiefs were my own. Witness. I returned them to him.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Powell's Defence. About half-past seven o'clock I left home, accom
panied by a female, to take a walk, and saw a great crowd, crying, "Stop thief! murder! thieves!" I left the female, and went through the mob, to the lady's house; I went into the yard, and staid there some time; some men were making their way over the pales; one of them made a violent blow at me with a stick or poker, which stunned me; on coming to, the mob was dispersed; I made towards the house I had come through, when the lady came out, accompanied by a young man, and seized me; I have a female to prove I was in her company at a quarter or half-past seven o'clock.

Munday's Defence. I was passing along the street, and heard the cry of "Stop thief;" I ran towards the crowd, and saw about two dozen people running from one yard to another, crying, "Thieves!" got over, and was taken into custody, as one of the thieves.

WILLIAM HARWOOD
re-examined. I found the bundle of things, all
loose, under a table in the shed, where Powell was found—nobody had been there but him.

POWELL—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

MUNDAY—
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fifteen Years.

992.
WILLIAM HODGES was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of February, 1 shilling, 3 sixpences, and 3 groats, the monies of
Joseph Stevens, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

993.
WILLIAM STRATTON and
WILLIAM PORTER were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February, 1/2 ton of coals, value 15s., the goods of
Robert William Samson and another, their masters.

CHARLES BUTTIVANT . I am in the employ of Robert William Samson and another, coal-merchants. The prisoners were their wagoner and porter—on the 20th of February I directed a wagon to be loaded, and afterwards saw it loaded, standing in the yard—there were four tons of coals in it—ten sacks were to be delivered at Maryland-terrace, Dover-road, and the remaining thirty at Mr. Nickerson's, of Berraondsey—the wagon returned empty, and went out again.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you see the forty sacks put into the wagon? A. No—I gave directions for four tons of coals to be put in—I did not weigh or measure them, or see them put in—I only saw the wagon when loaded.

THOMAS FOGO BURNEY . I am weigher to the prosecutors. On the 20th of February I weighed forty sacks of coals into a wagon, and delivered them to the prisoners, to be delivered at Mr. Frost's and Mr. Nickerson's.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see them put in? A. Yes—Pike and Co. had ordered the coals—they were the persons to whom we sold them—this ticket is one of Pike and Co.'s—it applies to these coals—it was given out by Buttiman.

CHARLES BUTTIVANT
re-examined. This is the ticket relating to these coals—Pipe and Co. purchased the coals of Mr. Samson, and their name was on the wagon—the prisoners were Messrs. Samson's servants.
WILLIAM PIPE . I supply my customers with coals, by giving orders to Messrs. Samson—I gave them orders to supply three tons of coals to Mr. Nickerson, and one ton to Mr. Frost.
Cross-examined. Q. The wagon was yours, we understand? A. No, it was Messrs. Samson's—my name was on it—it screwed on and off—it is a usual thing in the coal trade—I was the seller.
COURT. Q. Are you liable for the whole of the coals, or only for the quantity delivered? A. For whatever quantity was delivered, no more.

MARY ANN FROST . I am the wife of Thomas Frost, No. 18, Mary-land-place, Dover-road. On the 20th of February I received ten sacks of coals from Messrs. Samson's—I saw them delivered—there were other sacks in the wagon—the prisoners are the persons that delivered them.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you measure your coals after they were deli
vered? A. No—I saw them shot into the cellar—Mr. Frost ordered them of Mr. Pike—I knew nothing of Messrs. Samson.

CHARLES NICKERSON . I live in Bermondsey. On the 20th of Febru
ary some coals were delivered to me by the prisoners—after they were de
livered, Stratton came and asked me to come and see the sacks counted—I went, and be counted thirty—he appeared to count right—I saw five empty sacks in the wagon, and five full sacks—I asked Stratton, in Porter's hearing, what those five empty sacks were—he said they were five sacks that he bad left on the road—I also remarked about the five full sacks—he said they were five he had got to leave elsewhere—I gave him 6d. and they went away—when I looked at the coals afterwards, there appeared lets than I thought there should be—I locked the cellar door, and weighed them, on the following day, only those in the dye-house, not those in the house—I found half a ton deficient—there were very few coals in the cellar previously, not a quarter of a hundred weight—we had had a hundredweight in the day before.

Cross-examined. Q. When did these coals come in? A. Between one and two o'clock on Saturday, and I began weighing them about nine o'clock next day, and finished about eleven or twelve—there were some other coals shot into the house—I did not weigh them that morning—I did when the policeman came on the Wednesday following, and they were all quite right.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When did you lock your cellar up? A. Within a quarter of an hour of receiving the coals.
WILLIAM DYER . I am servant to Mr. Nickenon. I helped him to weigh the coals on Sunday morning, and found a deficiency of half a ton, or a little better—I knew what coals were in the cellar before.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

STRATTON—
GUILTY . Aged 33.

PORTER—
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Twelve Months.

994.
ROBERT TURNER was indicted
for an indecent assault.

GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

995.
JOHN BUTLER was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of February, 1 copper, value 20s., the goods of
Elizabeth West, and then being fixed to a certain building; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

996.
SARAH HUGGINS was indicted
for bigamy.

RICHARD BELL . I am sexton of St. George's Church, Southwark. I produce the register of the marriages at St. George's, Southwark—I do not keep the register, but at the last examination I was at Union-hall police-office, and was bound over—I have brought the book from its proper place of custody, the church—(reads—"On the 14th of January, 1838, William Huggins, aged 32, gentleman, batchelor, residing in Lant-street, son of William John Huggins, artist, married to Sarah Johnson, aged 25, widow, residing in Lant-street; father's name, Lawrence Filly, a fisherman; by me, JOHN HORTON, Rector.") I am one of the subscribing witnesses to the register, and Frances Bell, my wife, is another—William Steed was present—I furnished this copy (looking al one) to the police-officer, and examined it from this register, with the policeman—it is a correct copy—
it was copied by the clerk, and the entry in the book is his—I am not able to identify either of the persons who were married.

Rev. JOHN HORTON. I am Rector of St. George's, Southwark, I subscribed this register of marriage—the parties were married by me—I am not able to recognise either of them—I signed this book, but not the copy.

WILLIAM STEELE . I am parish-clerk of St. George's, Southwark. I wrote this copy of the register, it is a true copy—I was present at the marriage, but am not able to identity the parties—a copy of the register is generally given at the time of the marriage, and that is signed by the minister—a person applied to me for this copy, (I think it was the prose
cutor,) and I wrote it.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. When did you give this copy to any person? A. On the 11th of January, 1841—I do not know who—it was in the vestry—I think I delivered it to this gentleman, (Mr. Clothier, senior,) I know he is the prosecutor, but I cannot undertake to swear he was the person—I was at Union-hall police-office about a fortnight after I delivered the paper—I did not remember at that time to whom I delivered it—I think there was only one person when I delivered it.
FRANCES BELL . This is my handwriting as a witness to this marriage—I have no recollection of the parties.

EDWARD COLLIER . I am a printer, and live in Fenchurch-street, City. I know William Hugging, he is in Court—this "William Huggins" in this register, I presume to be his—I have seen him write frequently.

Cross-examined. Q. You merely presume it? A. I do not presume, I used a wrong expression—I am satisfied it is his—perhaps for three years I saw him write every day, in passing through the shop, from 1825 to 1827 or 1828.

ROBERT SAVAGE . I live in Johnson-street, St. George's-in-the-East, and am a tailor. I know the prisoner—she came to live next door but one to me, just about Christmas, 1836, with a person named Johnson, that she represented as her husband—he died there, three or four months after they came there, and was buried, I suppose—there was a funeral pro
cession, and every thing of that kind—I know Huggins, he lodged in the same house previous to Johnson's death—I have seen him there.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know any thing more? A. Mr. Huggins continued to live there with her till they went away, some time in August—I never heard of their being man and wife at that time—I do not in
sinuate any thing of that.

SAMUEL CANHAM . I live in Oxford-street, Mile-end, and am an un
dertaker. I know the prisoner—I knew her late husband, Johnson—I knew them living together as man and wife, in Johnson-street—he died in April, 1837—he was buried, and taken up again by order of the coroner, and then buried again at Wycliff chapel—I knew Huggins lodged in the same house with them in Grove-street, Commercial, and then they went to Chapman-street—I saw Huggins in Grove-street, and in Chapman-street—he followed Johnson to his funeral.

Cross-examined. Q. Where had you seen Huggins? A. At the resi
dence—I had not seen him in Johnson's company—they were lodgers—the landlady of the house in Grove-street, took the house in Chapman-street, and they were together—Johnson was the landlord of the house in Johnson-street, where he died—it was only a small house—I cannot say
which room Huggins had—I Raw him in the parlour there several times—Johnson was dead when I went to that house.
JAMES HOOKER . I am in the service of Mr. Bell, a fishmonger, in Fish-street-hill. I know the prisoner—her name was Sarah Filly before she was married—her father was a fisherman.
Cross-examined. Q. Where? A. At Gillingham, near Chatham—I did not know her after she was married—I saw her in town, and she said she was married.

GEORGE MORPHET . I am a painter. I know the prisoner, and I know William Huggins, who sits here—I know he and the prisoner lived together as man and wife, at the latter end of 1837, in New-square, Minories—they were not living at my house—they left New-square, and went to Richard-son-street, Long-lane, Bermondsey, to Mr. Southerby's, the hatter.

Cross-examined. Q. What time was it they left? A. I think about March, 1838, to the best of my recollection—they lived together exactly on the same terms all the time they were there, which was from about October.

FRANCIS SOUTHERBY . I am a hatter, and live at Bermondsey. On the 26th of March, 1838, the prisoner and William Huggins came to live in my apartments—they lived as man and wife till the middle of August in the same year—I very often heard the prisoner speak of Huggins as her husband, and sometimes as "William."
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see Clothier? A. No, he has not been to me, the policeman has—the prisoner has often said of a night, "Has my husband come in?" or "Has William come home?"

MARIA DUFFEL . I am the wife of William Duffel, we live in Union-street East-lane, Walworth. I have known the prisoner and William Huggins for rather better than two years—I knew them all in 1839 and 1840—they were living at No. 8, Wellington-place, East-lane—I was in the habit of going to work and char for them—I breakfasted there the first twelve months—I remember the prisoner leaving home rather better than twelve months ago—she told me she was going to Gillingham to her mother—she staid away from the Sunday till the Wednesday—on her return she sent for me, and I found her sitting by the parlour-fire crying—she said, "Oh! Duffel"—I said, "What is the matter?"—"Oh! Duffel," said she, "I have done it"—I said, "In the name of God, what have you done t"—she said, "I have got married"—"To who, "I said—she said, "To Mr. Clothier"—I said, "Dear me, I should be very sorry to be as you are, for do you know if they come forward perhaps they may transport you"—she said she was not afraid of that, for they were too fond of her—I afterwards assisted her to move her goods out of the house where she was living with Mr. Huggins, to Mr. Clothier's.

Q. When she lived with Huggins, and before she went away, as she told you, to Gillingham, did she and Huggins live as man and wife? A. Yes—she used to call him Bill, and he her Sarah—she one day showed me a certificate—she opened it, and I saw "William Huggins" and "Sarah Johnson" on it—she then put it into the copper-hole fire, as I was washing; that was the year before she was married—it is about thirteen months ago—when she put it into the fire I said, "Oh, what are you about?"—she said, "Never mind, money will get another"—I saw enough of it to know that it was a certificate of a marriage—I saw the name of a parish on it, but I could not see what—that was on the Thursday before.

she went to Gillingham—after she said she was married to Mr. Clothier, she said she could end her days happier with Mr. Clothier than she could with Mr. Muggins—she can read, but I do not think she can read writing—I never saw her write.

Cross-examined. Q. You removed the goods, did you? A. Yes, out of the house into the cart—I told Mr. Huggins before the goods were taken—he did not assist in taking them—he was not there at all—he used to go out about nine o'clock in the morning, I do not know what time he returned—when I told him the goods were going, he did not attempt to in
terfere—there were not a great many goods, a cart-load—Mr. Clothier is a pawnbroker, in the Borough-road, and he kept a broker's shop—I did not see those very goods exposed for sale at Clothier's—I have been to Clothier's house, but I never went after the goods went in—the prisoner told me the goods were going to Clothier's, and I told Huggins so—he said, "Never mind, Jet her do as she likes"—Huggins never told me to keep secret any connexion between him and the prisoner, nor did the pri
soner ever tell me so—she asked me to come and see her at Clothier's, but I never went—she came down to my house once or twice—she never told me of any connexion between her and Clothier before she said she was married to him—she always told me he was her husband's first cousin—I have seen him at the house very often—I have seen her husband go out, and Clothier come in in five minutes afterwards—when I mentioned to Huggins about moving the goods, he cried very much, and said, "Let her do as she likes"—I never knew that Huggins and Clothier saw each other—I did not tell Clothier that she was married to Huggins, I thought it was not my business, I thought he was her husband's first cousin— when he came he was shown into the front parlour—I used to leave him there frequently—I cannot say how long he staid.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you any reason to believe that Clothier knew that Huggins was her husband? A. I do not think he did, because she always used to tell me to keep it a secret from Mr. Huggins that Clothier came there—I do not think that Huggins ever saw Clothier.

BARTHOLOMEW HERRING (police-constable P 187.) I have produced the copy of the register here to-day—on the 1st of February I took the prisoner into custody at No. 34, Manor-place, Walworth—it was Clothier's father who fetched me—I found the prisoner in an up-stairs room—Mr. Clothier, senior, went into the room first—I told the prisoner she must come with me—I said to Mr. Clothier, "My charge is for intermarrying with your son, her former husband being alive"—I went down stairs while the prisoner dressed—I went up again, and in about a second she got ransacking a box, and took this paper out—I took it from her hand—she said, "This is my marriage certificate, which I got from Mr. Clothier," and she said, "Mr. Clothier got it at St. George's church"—on the following day, when I met her, I said, "Who is Richard Bell and Frances Bell?"—she said, "That is the man and woman that belong to the church; they gave me away when I was married"—I said, "What, the clerk and his wife?"—she said, "Yes"—she said she was very sorry for what she had done, that Mr. Huggins was always a good husband, and she was very sorry for ever getting married a second time—I see the words "Sarah Johnson, widow," on this certificate—I did not say any thing to her about it—I said, "Did Mr. Clothier know you were a married woman"—she said, "Yes"—she said she repre
sented herself to Mr. Clothier as a widow.

Cross-examined. Q. When did this last conversation take place? A. Partly on the first day and partly on the second day, when I met her—the first day I apprehended her, and took her before the Magistrate, and she was let go, on making an appointment to meet me the next day—the Magistrate did not enter into it the first time, neither of the husbands came forward—he did not say, on that occasion, that the first marriage was not sufficiently proved—he said so on one occasion—there were four or five examinations.

COURT. Q. Was it after you had told the Magistrate what you have told, us that he said it was not proved? A. No, at the first examination he did not enter into it—I did not tell the Magistrate on that occasion.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Was there any evidence at that time of the first marriage? A. Nothing more than what she stated to me the first day—she gave me the certificate, and the next day I asked her who this Ri
chard and Frances Bell were—I cannot say whether I asked her that day or the next—I think it was the next day—the certificate was produced when I first apprehended her, but it was not then that I asked her the question, to the best of my belief.

Q. Was the certificate in your hand on the second occasion? A. Yes, I opened it, and produced it to her, and I said, "Who is Richard Bell and Frances Bell," and she said, "The man and woman belonging to the church"—this passed in the King's Head public-house, where she pro
mised to meet me—Mr. Clothier, the father, gave me instructions to appre
hend her—he did not tell me they could not prove the marriage—the prisoner told me that Clothier knew she was a married woman—I said, "Did Mr. Clothier know you was married?"—she said, "Yes; because I represented myself as a widow."

Q. How came you to mention what you did to the Magistrate? A. After he entered into the case, he said there was not evidence, and then the solicitor for the prosecution asked me whether I had heard her say any thing—that was at one of the examinations—I think it might be the second, be did not enter into it the previous night—there was no solicitor the first evening—the first examination was the second time of going before the Magistrate—we went three tunes after that examination—I gave this evidence about the conversation more than once—after the first examination the Magistrate said there was not evidence enough—I had then given this evidence to the Magistrate.

Q. Did you not tell me it was after the first examination that you said this? A. Yes—I had been examined on the first examination—the soli
citor had spoken to me both before and after the examination—I had not given my evidence to the Magistrate at that time, I bad not said a word—I went forward, and gave my evidence about apprehending her—I cannot take my oath to all the words that passed.

Q. Did you say a word about the conversation till after you were spoken to by the solicitor? A. The solicitor had had conversation with me before I had been with the Magistrate at all—that was on the first examin
ation, the second time of going before the Magistrate—when I went first, I gave an account of apprehending the prisoner—I do not know that I was asked about any conversation—I stated that I got the certificate from her, and she said that was what she got from Mr. Clothier—I did not state that till after the solicitor had the conversation with me.

Q. Did you not tell us that the solicitor, in consequence of the Magis
trate's saying there was not evidence enough, asked you if you had heard
any thing? A. Yes, both before and after I went to the Magistrate—the solicitor came to me before he had heard a word.

COURT. Q. When was it the Magistrate said there was not evidence? A. On Tuesday, the 2nd of February, I had told the Magistrate what the prisoner said about the certificate, and after that he said this.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. When did you first mention to any body the conversation between you and the prisoner? A. On Tuesday, when I saw the solicitor, he asked what I had heard, and I think on my oath that I told him both before and after the Magistrate made the remark.
WILLIAM CLOTHIER . I am the prosecutor's brother—I live with him. I was present at his marriage with the prisoner on the 16th of February, 1840, at Trinity Church, Newington.
NOT GUILTY .

997.
JOHN DOUGLAS was indicted
that he, on the 12th of Sep
tember, at Wandsworth, with a certain pistol loaded with gunpowder and a leaden bullet, at and against
Harvey Garnett Phipps Tuckett, feloniously and unlawfully did shoot, with intent thereby, &c., feloniously, wilfully, and of his malice aforethought, to kill and murder him.—2nd COUNT, with intent to maim and disable him.—3rd COUNT, to do some grievous bodily harm.

THOMAS HUNT DANN . I am constable of the parish of Wimbledon—I have a house and mill on Wimbledon-common—I was at home about five o'clock in the afternoon of Saturday, the 12th of September last—I saw a four-wheel gentleman's private carriage, drawn by two horses, just against Mr. Currie's, nearly a quarter of a mile from my place—it was on the road which turns off the high road, leading to the mill, about 100 yards from the high road which leads from Wandsworth to Wimbledon—I saw two gentlemen coming from it, making their way further on the com
mon—they divided, one went into Wandsworth parish, and one remained in Wimbledon—about the same time I saw another carriage on the high road—the two carriages were about a quarter of a mile apart—I saw two gentlemen come from that carriage, and divide, one meeting the other in Wandsworth parish, and one going into Putney parish—I then suspected it was a duel, and called my wife upon the stage of the mill to watch—I attended to the mill for a few minutes—as soon as my wife called to me, and said she thought it was a duel, I went into the house and got my staff, with intent to go to the ground—I went towards the ground where the gentlemen were then assembled, and in the act of firing—there were four gentlemen there, two were firing—there were two shots fired just as I got to my gate, which is 220 yards from the ground—I heard the noise—I then advanced towards the spot—I got within about fifteen yards of the spot when the second shots were fired—two of the gentlemen were standing side face to each other, about twelve yards apart, and two were to the right of them—I heard two reports—I thought the gentleman nearest me was wounded, because he put his hand to his head, and stood limping, for that reason I went to the furthermost—I afterwards under
stood the wounded man to be Captain Tuckett—the other one that was standing with his face sideways was Lord Cardigan—I do not see any of those who were on the right, to be positive.—(At the request of Captain Douglas, three gentlemen were allowed to sit with him is the bar)—I went up to Lord Cardigan—I know nothing more of my own knowledge as to the gentleman being hit—I did not see any

blood—I did not observe whether his coat, waistcoat, or trowsers were torn, as if by a shot—he walked rather lame afterwards, as he went up to my house from the ground—I had no acquaint
ance with Captain Tuckett before, or with any of the other parties—he gave me a card with "Captain Harvey Tuckett" on it—I had no other knowledge of his names than what he gave me—I am not certain who gave me the card, either Captain Tuckett or Captain Wainwright gave it me, as they were described to me, but I do not know either of them—I know no more of the persons who were standing to my right—my attention was then chiefly drawn to Lord Cardigan—I bad some conversation with him.

Cross-examined by MR. THESIGER. Q. How long have you been constable of Wimbledon? A. Two years—my first appointment was from the Court Leet—I carry on business as a miller—I had some notion of what the parties were about—I was in my mill about five or ten minutes, after giving my wife instructions about going on the stage of the mill, I went on my business, and was absent a quarter of an hour, it might be—I have been examined on this matter several times—I was before the Grand Jury three times in one day, on different indictments—some of them were thrown out—I will not undertake to say how many—there were true bills found against Lord Cardigan and Captain Douglas—I gave the same evi
dence that I have to-day—my wife, and my son, and Busain, were before the Grand Jury.

SARAH DANN . I am the wife of Thomas Hunt Dann—I was at home about five o'clock on the 12th of September last—I had not observed any thing before my husband spoke to me—my husband gave me some intima
tion—in consequence of that, I went to the slage of the mill—I saw five gentlemen in different directions on Wimbledon Common—I cannot say how far they were asunder—I saw one carriage standing on the road leading to the mill, and one on the high road—there were two gentlemen stooping down opposite the gate of the mill, about two hundred yards from the mill—they were stooping down three or four minutes—they got up again when they had been down three or four minutes—there was no other gentlemen near them—the others were walking at a distance, where they were before—they then drew near to the gentlemen who had been kneeling down—they were beckoned to by the two gentlemen who had been kneel
ing down, and they hastened towards them—when they came up, the two that beckoned them, handed each of them a pistol—upon that, the two gentlemen who had received the pistols, turned a side face to each other, and fired—there were two pistols fired—I heard two reports near each other—about that time I gave information to my husband, immediately after the first shot—he was just outside the gate—I called to him to run—he was going to
wards them—I did not go any nearer—I saw another shot fired—I was still standing on the same place, on the stage of the mill—the second shots were fired as soon as they had received the second pistols—they stepped a few paces and got the pistols, and then stepped back into the same place—the fifth man was standing at a greater distance, at the end of Mr. Currie's garden, about two hundred yards from the others—the garden is between the high road from Putney to Wimbledon and our mill—after the second shots had been fired, I remained on the stage of my mill—the gentlemen moved towards the mill—two came first, and three afterwards—I saw the two that came first, move from the spot where the firing had been, towards the mill—they went past the mill into our house—I was still upon the

stage—the other three had not passed—I saw them coming close to the gate, before I went off the stage—I can say that the two that first came, and two out of the three that came the second lime, were the four that had been standing, as I describe, when the firing book place—I am sure of that—I saw the fifth join them, from Carrie's garden—I had never seen any of these parties before, to my knowledge—I am not certain that I should know the whole of them—I should know some if I saw them—I should know Lord Cardigan, and I think I should know Captain Wainwright—I think the second gentleman from me at the bar (Captain Douglas) is the gentle
man that was wounded—I do not know that I see any other gentleman that was there—I did not see any other persons there besides the four that had been standing on the ground, and the one that came up from Currie's garden, and my husband and son—of those five gentlemen that came up, one was wounded, and I think the gentleman is the bar resembles him—I cannot swear to him—the reason I think the gentleman was wounded was, he unfastend his clothes—there was no tear on his trowsers or coat as if a shot had passed through—I did not see any blood—I saw them apparently place a white handkerchief on the place that he jointed out on his hip, when his clothes were undone—I saw a basin of discoloured water, and a stained towel, after they had left the room—they had asked for water of me—the water had been stained from washing a wound, I suppose—it appeared to be stained with blood, and so did the towel—I was not before the Justices at Wandsworth—I was before the Grand Jury—I never appeared as a witness, until I was in the House of Lords.

SEBASTIAN BYRON DANN . I am fourteen years old, and am the son of Thomas Hunt Dann. I was at home about five o'clock in the evening of the 12th of September—I was with my mother, on the stage of the mill—I observed two carriages, one was on the road leading from the high towards our mill from the common, and the other on the high itself—I saw five gentlemen when J was at the gate, and they were on the common; two in one part, two in another, and one by himself, at the cor
ner of Mr. Currie's garden—the first two were on the common together, and the other two were together—the first two were in Wimbledon parish, and the other two were in Putney parish—the two parties separated, and walked about for a little while—one of each party then joined, they went and knelt down together—I saw them get up, and go and stand back to back—the other two were walking about at that time—the two that knelt down then walked five or six paces, and beckoned to the other two—when the two were beckoned to they were separate, and two gentlemen came up ac
cordingly—when they came up, they each took a pistol and fired at each other—they stood side-face—there were two shots fired—it was both toge
ther—I am sure there were two reports—there were two smokes from the pistols—the reports were together—it was one sound, as if it had been one pistol—I then came down from the stage of the mill, and went behind my father about fifty yards—we were going towards them—as we were going, I saw and heard another shot—it sounded as one—there were two smokes—when I got to the gentlemen I found one of them was wounded, and I saw the fifth man undo his trowsers—I saw some blood just on the hip—the gentleman put his hand to his side, and walked very limping—I went with them to our mill—I walked with all of them—one was gone for a carriage—two of the gentlemen walked on, and two were behind with my father—I saw them both upon the ground, and walking towards our house

—all five—I did not know any of them before—I have since seen Lord Cardigan, the one who shot—I have not seen any other since—I cannot say that I see any in this Court that were upon the spot on that day—I cannot see any one that I can recognise—I do not know any of the gentle
men that are sitting in the bar, as being the gentlemen either upon the ground or at our house—I was not before the Magistrates at Wandsworth—I have been before the Grand Jury, and been examined before the House of Lords and at the Home-office—when the gentleman whose trowsers were undone came out of the bouse, he was put into a carriage and drove off, and two more gentlemen with him in the same carriage—I do not know any of the five but the Earl of Cardigan.

SIR JAMES EGLINTON ANDERSON . I am a physician. My answering whether I was at Wimbledon on the 12th of September last may involve myself in some difficulty—I trust your Lordship will not press it—I am apprehensive that, answering that question, I may be in some difficulty, and have some charge brought against me—any question affecting Captain Tuckett may implicate myself—I do not know where Captain Tuckett is.
Q. How long is it since you have seen him? A. The whole bearing of the question would lead ultimately to implicate myself in this transaction—I trust your Lordship will not press me to answer.
Q. Was he well or ill when you last saw him? A. I fear the same answer must be given to that.

Q. Then I understand you to object to answer any questions respecting a visit to Wimbledon in September last? A. I do—I am afraid of impli
cating myself.

JOHN BUSAIN . I am police-inspector of Wandsworth. I was so in Sep
tember last—a little before six o'clock in the evening of the 12th of Septem
ber last two cases of duelling-pistols were given me by Dann the miller—I have still the custody of them—they are here—I know Lord Cardigan—he came into the station before the pistols were delivered—I know nothing of the duel—Captain Douglas was with Lord Cardigan—he gave his name, "John Douglas, Captain of the 11th Hussars," by word of mouth—that was on Saturday evening, before there was any inquiries before the Justices—they did not go before the Justices till Monday morning—I took down the charge from Dann, who gave charge of them—it was taken in writing—I have not got it here—I was not ordered to bring it—I had it at the House of Lords—I took down Captain Douglas's address, "At Lord Cardigan's, No. 26, Portman-square"—I took down what Captain Douglas said in writing, in the original sheet, which is always sent in to Whitehall—I took down the name of Captain Douglas in writing, as well as the charge pre
ferred by Dann against Lord Cardigan and Captain Douglas—I know the person of Captain Douglas—he is the second gentleman sitting, from here, in the bar—Lord Cardigan and he were together in the station till they were bailed, which was almost immediately after—when Lord Cardigan came in, he said he was a prisoner, he believed—I said, "What for?"—his lordship put his hand into his pocket to give me a card, and he dropped some—I took them up—he gave me one—he said he was a prisoner, he believed—I said, "What for?"—he said, he had been fighting a duel, he believed, and as Captain Douglas came up the steps, he pointed his fingers over his shoulder, and said, "So is this gentleman also, my second, Captain Douglas"—a' part of the conversation took place before Captain Dougras came up; and Lord Car
digan said he was a prisoner, he believed—Captain Douglas could hear that—he was close euough to have heard it—I do not remember that he

made any remark upon it—Captain Douglas did not say any thing—I should think my station at Wandfworth is two miles from the mill at Wimbledon—it was about a quarter to six in the evening of the 12th of September when they were brought to the station.

Cross-examined by MR. THESIGER. Q. As I understand, Dann the miller came with a charge to you? A. Yes, and I took down the charge in the charge sheet—the prosecutor signs it, it is then taken before the Magistrate at the earliest sitting, and after the Magistrate signs his name, and marks off his decision, it is sent to the superintendent's office, and then sent to the commissioners, where it is kept—the station is nearly in the centre of the town of Wandsworth—there are only two steps to the door, one stone step, and the door-sill—Lord Cardigan had been in the station a minute before he pointed, as I have described—a conversation had taken place between me and him—there was no other person in the station—the station is very small, it is not larger than this lobby—Lord Cardigan was in the outer room at this time, which was separated from the little room by a wooden partition—he had his back to the door of entry, facing the fire—I was between him and the door—I was farther from the door of entry than Lord Cardigan—when Lord Cardigan pointed, Captain Douglas had just stepped up to the door-sill—he had just come into the office—it takes no time to come up the steps—it is true that when Lord Cardigan said what he did, Captain Douglas was coming up the steps—I was close by Lord Cardigan—there was not the least occasion for Lord Cardigan to speak loud to make me hear.

COURT. Q. When this was actioned by Lord Cardigan, was any writ
ing going on? A. No, it was before I began to take the charge—Captainv Douglas gave his name and address when I was writing the charge.
THOMAS BICKNELL . I am superintendent of the V division of police, which embraces Wandsworth and Wimbledon. I have no evidence to give, farther than being public prosecutor.

THOMAS HUNT DANN
re-examined. There were five gentlemen alto
gether in the yard—I can undertake to say that those five were the four that were on the ground, and the fifth at Currie's garden—I am sure of that—a card was given me by some one, who I understood was Captain Tuckett, or Captain Wainwright—the other two were close to me at the time—they were all five in the yard—Lord Cardigan was farthest from me—I do not remember any thing being said when the card was given me, any more than it was a card of their address—this is the card—(producing it.)

THOMAS BICKNELL
re-examined. I was bound over to prosecute—there is the Magistrate's clerk from Wandsworth here, named Fletcher—I am not aware what description of evidence he has to give.

GEORGE CHARLES FLETCHER . I was subpœned a few days ago by Mr. Hobler, the solicitor for the prosecution, and I attended here in conse
quence—I know nothing of the transaction except the circumstances which took place before the Magistrates—I am their clerk—the depositions were returned to this Court, they did not go to the House, of Lords in the first instance—there were other depositions taken besides those on the previous examination of the prisoners, and the substance of them is embodied in this evidence, which is the final examination—I am not aware of any evi
dence except those whose names have been called.

There being no proof of Captain Tuckett's Christian names, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

998.
SARAH PETERS was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of February, 1 sheet, value 2s. 6d.; and 1 blanket, value 2s.; the goods of
Joseph Wilkinson, her master.

JOSEPH WILKINSON . I am a shoemaker, and live in Kent-street. The prisoner was in my employ for a month—I keep a lodging-house, and she had the care of the beds—on the 22nd of February I missed a sheet and a blanket—these are them.
SAMUEL HOBELL . I am a pawnbroker. This sheet and blanket were pledged by the prisoner, on the 22nd of February.
Prisoner. I was sent by my master to pawn a handkerchief about half, past eight o'clock, and I was not in the shop after that. Witness. I am sure she is the person.

GUILTY .* Aged 42.—
Confined Four Months.

999.
WILLIAM WOODWARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of February, 150lbs. weight of lead, value 1l. 1s., the goods of
Sir Edward George Earle Litton Bulwer, Baronet; and fixed to a certain building.

ALEXANDER MCCASKERY (police-sergeant V 14.) On the 13th of Feb
ruary I was on my beat at Fulham—I met the prisoner about a mile from the prosecutor's, about a quarter past eight o'clock in the morning, wheel
ing a barrow—I asked what he was carrying—he said, "Slates"—I asked whose employ he was in—he said, "Mr. Dodd, of Fulham"—I asked him to open the bag, and let me see what he had got—he refused, and said he would go back to his employer's—I took'him, and found this leaden gutter in the sack which he was wheeling—I went on the prosecutor's premises, and found the whole leaden gutter had been taken from a stable—it fitted exactly—it had been wrenched off, and the nail holes tallied.

STEPHEN SIMPSON . I am gardener to Sir Edward George Earle Litton Bulwer, Bart. I saw this lead fitted to the stable, where it had been fixed—it tallies in all respects—I know nothing of the prisoner.
GEORGE BOWER . I live about two hundred yards from the prisoner—he borrowed a barrow of me that morning to take a sack of potatoes, as he said—he had a sack under his arm at the time.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. All his life—I had no suspicion of any thing wrong—I believe he has been out of work, and, by what I understand, rather distressed—he has a wife, but no family.

GUILTY .** Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1000.
THOMAS TRIMMER was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of February, 1 loaf of bread, value 4 1/2 d., the goods of
James Starmer Brett.
JAMES STARMER BRETT . I lost this loaf from my cart, which was at Mrs. Graham's gate, at Clapham, on the 19th of February—this is the loaf.
JOSEPH WAIN . I saw the prisoner take a loaf out of the cart—he walked a little way, and then ran—I told Mr. Brett, who took him.
Prisoner. I was not there, I was working in a garden.

(The prisoner received a good character, and his master engaged to em
ploy him again.)

GUILTY. Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Eight Days.

1001.
MARY MARGETTS was indicted
for casting herself into the river Thames, with intent wilfully, &c., to kill, drown, and murder herself, —2nd COUNT, for swallowing a quantity of laudanum, with intent to kill, &c.; to which she pleaded

1002.
WILLIAM GANT was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Feb
ruary, 21 yards of silk, value 3l. 10s.; 10 yards of mouseline-de-laine, value 8s.; 270 yards of galloon, value 1l.; 3 pairs of gloves, values 8s.; 2 pairs of drawers, value 5s. 6d.; 8 collars, value 5s.; 1 stock, value 6d.; 1 shirt, valued.; 9 handkerchiefs, value 1l. 16s.; and 3 scarfs, value 1l. 10s.; the goods of
Joseph Pobjoy Harvey, his master.

ROBERT SCOTT . I am shopman to Joseph Pobjoy Harvey, a linen-draper, in the Westminster-road, Lambeth. The prisoner was in bis em
ploy—on the morning of the 15th of February, about half-past seven o'clock, I saw the prisoner go from the shop down to the lower warehouse—I there heard him open some parcels, and on looking down, I saw him with a paper open, containing some challi dresses—I went down—he met me, and appeared confused—I made some remark to him, and then re
turned to the dwelling-house, secreted myself on the landing of the stain—soon after, became up in a great hurry, and I thought I observed some
thing bulky under his coat—I mentioned my suspicion to Mr. Tomlinsin about half an hour—on the 17th I again saw the prisoner go down to an
other part of the warehouse, and open some galloon papers, he bad got his blouse coat on, as he had before—I told Mr. Wilson.

ROBERT TOMLIN . I am shopman to Mr. Harvey. On this second oc
casion the prisoner passed me as he came from the warehouse—he had a blouse coat on, and I saw he had something concealed—I went and spoke to Mr. Wilson.

HUGH WILSON . I am principal assistant to Mr. Harvey. The wit
nesses spoke to me—I had the prisoner before his master—Mr. Harvey told him that he suspected him—he said he did not know what he alluded to, did he suspect his honesty—Mr. Harvey said yes—the policeman was sent for, and then the prisoner desired to speak to Mr. Harvey, which Mr. Harvey declined—the officer then desired him to go to his sleeping apart
ment, which he did, and pointed out his boxes, and gave up the keys—there were several articles taken out, some of which I knew myself—he went to the other side of the bed while the search was going on, and, from some exclamation, the officer went round and found him in the act of cut
ting his throat—the officer seized him, and he dropped the razor.
WILLIAM STANNARD . I am a police-inspector. I took the prisoner—I produce this silk, galloon and other things, which were found in the prisoner's box.
HUGH WILSON . There are marks on many of these articles, which leave no doubt that they are my master's.

GUILTY. Aged 27.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined One Year.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1003.
WILLIAM MOORE was indicted
for fraud.

JOHN CHANNER (police-sergeant M 24.) I was on duty at the station, on the 5th of January, in Southwark-bridge-road—while there the pri
soner came to me—he said that he was a deserter from the 60th Regiment of Rifles, and wished to give himself up, being quite destitute—I went before Mr. Trail, the Magistrate, with him, and there saw him sign this paper—I likewise saw Mr. Trail sign it—(read)—"The prisoner delivered himself up, at the police station, to John Charmer, and slated himself to be a deserter; I do certify that the prisoner has been examined, and declares he is a deserter from the before-mentioned corps.
"D. TRAIL".
"WILLIAM MOORE .
"JOHN CHANNER .
JOHN STYLES . I am principal turnkey at Horsemonger-lane prison. I received the prisoner into custody on the 5th of January—he continued with me forty-one days, which, at 6d. a day, is 20s. 6d.

SERGEANT CROOK. I belong to the 1st battalion of the 60th Rifles. The prisoner was formerly in that regiment, and was discharged about the 21st of January, 1836, at Malta—he has not been in the regiment since.
The following certificate was here read:—

"At the General Quarter Sessions, at Devizes, in the third year, &c., William Moore, labourer, was indicted, tried, and convicted, for that he, on the 31st of August, was convicted as a rogue and vagabond, in Kent and at Devizes, having surrendered himself as a deserter, did pretend that he was a deserter from the 1st battalion of the 60th Rifles, by which false pretence he did then and there obtain from Thomas Haywood 1l. 10s., to defraud him of the same; whereas he was not a deserter from her Ma
jesty's forces; he was ordered to be imprisoned in the New Prison at Devizes eighteen months.
"WILLIAM F. SALMONS."
Witness. He was tried at Devizes—I was present, and he had eighteen months—he is the same person.

GUILTY .** Aged 30.—
Transported for Seven Years.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, APRIL 5TH, 1841.
